[Operator Instructions] I'd like to advise the parties that this conference may be recorded for replay purposes. 
And now, I'd like to hand to Tim. Please go ahead.

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call to discuss ADT's first quarter results for fiscal year 2015. With me on the call today are Naren Gursahaney, ADT's CEO; and Mike Geltzeiler, ADT's CFO. Let me begin by reminding everyone that the discus
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our call to discuss ADT's first quarter results for fiscal year 2015. 
With me on the call today are Naren Gursahaney, ADT's CEO; and Mike Geltzeiler, ADT's CFO. 
Let me begin by reminding everyone that the discussion today contains certain forward-looking statements about the company's future performance, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties and speak only as of today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ from these forward-looking statements are set forth within today's release, which was furnished to the SEC in an 8-K report, and in our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended December 26, 2014, which we expect to file with the SEC later today. 
In our first quarter 2015 earnings release and slides, which are now posted on our website at adt.com and on our Investor Relations app, we have provided a reconciliation of the company's non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP. We urge you to review that information in conjunction with today's discussion. For those of you following on the webcast, we will be using this slide deck to supplement our commentary this morning. Please note that, unless otherwise mentioned, references to our operating results exclude special items, in these metrics are non-GAAP measures. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Naren. Naren?

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. I hope you have a chance to review our earnings press release we issued early this morning that highlights our results for the first quarter of 2015. This morning, I'll discu
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. I hope you have a chance to review our earnings press release we issued early this morning that highlights our results for the first quarter of 2015. 
This morning, I'll discuss our key performance highlights and accomplishments for the quarter, then Michael Geltzeiler will provide additional details on our financial and operational performance. 
As you can see from our results, we've continued the trends we saw in the second half of 2014, and we're off to a strong start to the new year, delivering another quarter of improved performance. 
Solid execution of our initiatives is driving stronger financial and operational results and the investments we continue to make in our business are positioning us for future profitable revenue growth. 
All of our key customer metrics continued to move in the right direction during the quarter as we take advantage of our industry-leading position and strong brand recognition. 
We remain excited about what we see in the business today and the evolution occurring in our industry that is creating even more opportunities for future growth. I'm proud of our team's performance this quarter, while recognizing the opportunity for an even brighter future. 
As we review our highlights for the quarter, I think it's important to look at our performance in the context of our strategy and against the backdrop of our rapidly evolving industry. We've made significant progress since becoming a standalone company a little over 2 years ago. This progress has accelerated over the past several quarters as we begun to benefit from the initiatives that we have pursued to enhance our operations and competitive position, resulting in improvements in our performance. 
This quarter, we continue to invest in growth and strengthening our leadership team, all in support of our strategy to achieve our vision for ADT. A vision that is rooted in extending our leadership position in the security, life safety and home automation markets, enhancing the values of ADT's services and executing on our initiatives to drive strong returns. 
A common thread running throughout every aspect of our vision is creating a superior customer experience. The results from the actions we've taken are continuing to shine through in our results, giving us confidence that we're on the right path. 
As I've discussed on previous calls, I view the recent activity in our industry in 2 distinct areas: Integrated professionally monitored security life safety and automation solutions, where ADT is traditionally focused currently serving about 20% of households; and unmonitored or self monitored standalone home automation solutions where many new entrants, large and small, are focusing their efforts on the remaining 80% of households. 
The majority of these efforts are targeting a wide range of home automation applications with only a small portion addressing security and life safety. 
While our traditional market is more competitive than it was 5 years ago, the environment has been relatively stable and we're continuing to win in this market, as evidenced by our improving operational and customer metrics and solid financial results. 
Slide 3 shows our strong performance over the past 12 months on 4 key metrics that are affected by the competitive environment. 
Over the past years, we have driven increases in gross adds in all lines of business and in our direct and dealer channels. Improved customer retention by 120 basis points increased the average price paid by newly added customers and reduced our creation multiple, or in other words, the cost we incurred to bring on a new customer.  I think this chart is the best evidence that we are winning in the market and our performance is accelerating. 
Specifically, for the first quarter, as highlighted on Slide 4, we drove double-digit gross subscriber growth with year-over-year increases on both our direct and authorized dealer channels for the first time since 2013, driven by stronger lead generation, increases in our self generated business and improved closed rates. 
Unit and revenue attrition continue to improve meaningfully versus prior year and sequentially as we reduced attrition to its lowest level since we became a public company. 
As a result of these improvements in gross adds and customer retention, we narrowed our net subscriber loss significantly and are focused on returning to growing net subscribers. 
From a financial perspective, our improved operational performance allowed us to deliver strong recurring revenue growth, increased EBITDA margins and bottom line results on a year-over-year basis. 
Because of the strong returns we drive in our business today and the many opportunities we see that generate profitable growth in the years ahead, we continue to invest in ADT's future as shown on Slide 5. 
We're investing to enhance the customer experience by implementing new technologies and processes, including the rollout of a new electronic order management platform and the deployment of our new wireless Total Security Panel.  We're expanding our presence in the midsize commercial market and making investments in products and distribution to generate future growth through our health service offerings. 
We also added a new key leader to run our combined business in Canada and appointed a new Board member from the technology sector, Chris Hylen of Citrix Systems. 
We're also continuing to invest in driving profitable growth through Pulse. Pulse continues to be an important driver behind our results, and in Q1, Pulse take rates increased as did Pulse upgrades. 
As you can see on Slide 6, over 53% of our total gross adds during the quarter were Pulse units, up from 51% last quarter and 37% a year ago. 
In our residential direct channel, the Pulse take rate for new and resale units was nearly 57%, up 15 percentage points over the same quarter last year and 71% of all new residential customers added via our direct sales channels were Pulse customers. 
In our small business channel, the Pulse take rate was 50%, up 14 percentage points over the first quarter of last year. 
In our dealer channel, the Pulse take rate ramped to 50% from about 40% -- 47% last quarter and 29% last year. 
In addition to new system sales of Pulse, we upgraded about 31,000 existing customers this quarter. This is nearly doubled the number we did in the same period last year. 
Our Pulse upgrade efforts allow us to provide additional functionality to our existing customers and yield higher ARPU. 
In addition, these upgrades allow us to enter into new contracts with these customers and enhance the customer experience. 
I'm happy with the progress we're making in our operations and with the investments that we're making in our future. 
Before turn I turn the call over to Mike, I want to share some of my thoughts on the evolving landscape in our industry and some observations from the Consumer Electronics Show that took place earlier this month. 
At CES this year, the connected home and Internet of Things continue to gain significant traction. In fact, there was an entire venue dedicated to the connected home and IoT innovations, where ADT was well represented and traffic was very robust. 
The conference showcased several new technology companies, along with many of the biggest names in the consumer electronics industry, offering point solutions for the connected world and smart home. 
ADT's prominent presence in the event featured several of our products with a primary focus on Pulse. In fact, Pulse was recognized by Time Magazine as one of the 6 Coolest Smart Home Innovations at the show. 
Pulse was also featured in a CES keynote addressed by Brian Krzanich, the CEO of Intel, who demonstrated the integration of Pulse with Intel Securities true key multifactor authentication to provide a new level of security and convenience for users. 
This jointly developed proof of concept was held by Brian as an example of how our IoT partnership can make a smart home also a safe home. 
At CES, we also showcased our new total security wireless panel for Pulse automation installations, which we rolled out last quarter and installed approximately 8,000 units during the quarter. 
What I saw at CES this year reinforced several thoughts on ADT's positioning for the future. 
First, much of the product innovation and many new point solutions are geared towards the 80% of the market, not reached or targeted by traditional professional installed and monitored security and automation solutions. The growing interest in this segment is raising the awareness of and the growth opportunity for monitored security and home automation. 
Second, these self monitored smart home solutions are not necessarily creating a safe home as notifying and seeing are not the same as monitoring. 
Additionally, customers are growing weary of the large and growing number of apps needed to manage all the disparate devices in their home. Most customers prefer to have a single platform with an easy and unified customer experience to manage their connected home. 
Finally, a primary driver of consumer interest in smart home applications is security. This was reinforced by recent research conducted by several third parties, including Lowe's and the Consumer Electronics Association. 
I believe ADT is well positioned to capture additional growth in the future given our large customer base, trusted brand, robust monitoring infrastructure, strong field sales and installation force and fully developed Pulse platform. ADT is viewed as a partner of choice by many well respected companies in the industry. 
I believe that ADT is in the right place, at the right time, with the right platform, services and products to capitalize on this opportunity to make homes and businesses both smart and safe. 
Now let me turn things over to Mike to provide some additional details on our financial and operational performance during the quarter.

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Naren. As Naren mentioned, we're off to a strong start this year, delivering another quarter of improved financial and operational results. The metrics that drive our business are moving in the right direction, and we continue to invest in new gro
componenttext:
Thanks, Naren. As Naren mentioned, we're off to a strong start this year, delivering another quarter of improved financial and operational results. The metrics that drive our business are moving in the right direction, and we continue to invest in new growth opportunities in health and commercial security. We're working diligently on improving our customers' experience. 
While we're committed to delivering improved financial performance, as evidenced by the strong start to the year, we have an ambitious plan to invest and build on these results to create a better ADT for both our customers and shareholders. This includes investing to improve customer experience, automating and streamlining processes, opening our platform to partners, expanding our services and distribution and integrating our Canadian businesses. 
Over the next few slides, I'll review our Q1 performance and highlight our accomplishment during the quarter. 
Slide 8 provides an overview of our GAAP and non-GAAP results. Recurring revenue grew 6.5% to $825 million and accounted for 93% of our total revenue. Our total revenue rose 5.7%. 
When adjusting for the decline in the Canadian dollar, recurring revenue was up over 7% and total revenue increased by 6.4%. 
We remain focused on growing our business through a highly profitable recurring revenue model, continuing the trend you've seen in our historical results. We continue to integrate Protectron into our results as we recognize a full quarter of contribution in Q1. Protectron contributed over half of the recurring revenue growth in the period, but since it currently operates at the lower margin in the ADT Business, the consolidation had a dilutive impact to EBITDA margins, increased our D&A and was neutral on EPS. 
EBITDA before special items for the quarter was $453 million, up 6% or $27 million over prior year. The weak Canadian dollar diluted this growth by $1.5 million. This translated to an EBITDA margin of 51.1%, an increase of 30 basis points year-over-year. 
Excluding the dilutive impact of Protectron, EBITDA margins before special items increased by nearly 100 basis points from last year. 
Year-over-year, recurring revenue growth, combined with our cost efficiency initiatives, drove the increase in our margins. 
Cost to serve was up 6% due primarily to the consolidation of Protectron. However, without Protectron, cost-to-serve expenses were flat with last year despite a higher mix of Pulse subscribers, additional investments and customer experience and launching our customer business. 
GAAP EPS was $0.41 a share, which includes special items and a tax rate in the quarter of 33.3%. Excluding special items, non-GAAP diluted EPS was $0.51, up 19% from Q1 2014. 
Using our Q1 tax cash tax rate of 4.6%, our earnings per share before special items was $0.73 for the quarter, up 11% over last year. 
The chart also details our special items for the quarter. In Q1, we accelerated the conversion of 2G radio customers, successfully converting 113,000 customers, a portion of which we were able to up-sell to ADT Pulse. 
We also incurred a minor level of integration expenses related to Protectron acquisition, as well as some restructuring charges. 
Activity to integrate Protectron will accelerate following the recent appointment of a new President for our combined Canadian operations. Our 2G conversion program will continue through 2016. We are comfortably ahead of plan and are opportunistically balancing this program against resource availability and customer demand. 
Turning to the operating leverage. Slide 9 shows strong gross adds growth and increases in average revenue per unit for Q1 versus the prior year. 
Total company gross adds increased over 13% year-over-year, driven by improved performance in our direct and dealer channels, as well as across our residential business and health units. 
Gross adds in our direct channel were up 10%, marking the first time we've experienced year-over-year growth since 2013. The increase in gross additions with stronger lead generation, higher close rates and greater self-generated sales. 
Protectron accounted for about 20% of the growth rate in the direct channel. New subscriber growth was accomplished despite the headwinds caused by our fully implemented enhanced credit screening procedures, which management estimates filtered out about 4,000 potential sales. 
We expect this enhanced processed to improve further future attrition by filtering credit-challenged customers into different payment plans, which allows us to focus on profitable growth. 
Gross adds in our dealer channel rose 19% from last year as we experienced higher sales from existing dealers, added some new dealers and benefited from the dealer volume production of Protectron. 
Returning dealer volumes to growth was a 2014 priority, which we've accomplished in Q4. We are very pleased with our partners, delivering 100,000 customer ads for Q1, a 16,000 increase over Q1 2014. 
Our ability to grow ARPU shows that pricing remains healthy in our business. Our continued investment in ADT Pulse, combined with incremental service offerings like small business bundles and hosted video, have helped drive higher revenue per user. 
For the quarter, new and resale ARPU was $47.28, an increase of 5% over the prior year and ARPU for our overall customer base was $41.76, an increase of 2% year-over-year. 
As a reminder, Protectron generates lower ARPU than our traditional base in the U.S. which diluted the overall year-over-year growth figure as did the weaker Canadian dollar.  Excluding Protectron, ARPU rose 4% over last year. 
Over the course of the last year, we launched a number of initiatives designed to improve the customer experience and increase customer retention. Our results on Slide 10 show that these initiatives are paying off as we improve attrition for the third consecutive quarter and reduce it to its lowest level since becoming a public company. 
Q1 trailing 12-month net revenue attrition was 13.0%. The sequential improvement of 50 basis points and a significant reduction of 120 basis points versus Q1 prior year. 
Unit attrition, which measures customer attrition for just our residential and business customers, was 12.9% for the quarter, a 30-basis-point improvement versus Q4 and 70 basis points lower than last year. 
Our focus on enhancing the customer experience, reducing nonpaid disconnections and increasing resales, coupled with stable existing home sales, contributed to lower attrition. 
The key to driving higher recurring revenues is increasing average revenue per customer through new offerings, greater automation and price escalations, all of which we are executing well, as well as growing the subscriber base. 
For the past 2 years, we have grown our subscriber base primarily as a result of M&A. Organically, we reported a net subscriber loss of over 100,000 customers in 2014. 
As we progress our dual goals of growing gross adds and lowering attrition, we are positioning the company towards its ultimate objective of organic net subscriber growth. 
In the first quarter, we reported a decline in our customer base of 8,000 subscribers. However, this compares favorably to Q1 2014, where we lost 48,000 customers. This is a major step forward and bodes well for future revenue growth. 
Slide 11 shows recurring revenue margin in SAC. For the quarter, recurring revenue margin on our existing customer base was 66.4%, up 10 basis points versus prior year. The current quarter included investments in our commercial expansion and health business, the dilutive effect of consolidating Protectron and efficiency from the Tyco separation. 
Excluding Protectron, recurring revenue margins would have been 67%, an increase of 70 basis points. 
And as I mentioned earlier, cost-to-serve expenses flat with last year on higher revenues. 
We continue to make progress in driving down customer acquisition costs and lowering our overall net creation multiple despite higher Pulse take rates, which require a larger upfront investment. 
Excluding the impact of Pulse upgrades, our combined net creation multiple improved by 0.7x to 31.7 in Q1, while the net creation multiple in our direct channel fell to 31.9x, a 2.1x improvement from last year. 
As a reminder, the first quarter is historically our highest level of SAC mostly due to absorption issues, and it's the lowest quarter of volumes. 
Average net SAC, excluding upgrades for our direct channel, was about $,1,500 per unit, which was actually below the same figure last year despite the increased sales of more expense of Pulse and automation units. This was possible because of productivity improvements, marketing savings and hardware efficiency. 
In the quarter, we began deploying our new Total Security Panel from new Pulse automation customers, continued our implementation of electronic contracts and delivered on our cost efficiency programs. ADT Business has now rolled out e-contract nationally and Resi will do the same in February. 
As mentioned earlier, we are investing in our business, in customer growth, Pulse, commercial expansion, health and customer experience, all in order to build a stronger and more profitable subscriber base. 
On Slide 12, we detail the components of free cash flow for the quarter. Cash flow from operations, before special items, was up 14% from last year to $390 million. 
The increase in operating cash flow is driven by past investments, our improved financial and operational performance in the quarter and improvements in working capital management. This 14% growth is despite a $25 million year-over-year increase in cash interest expense, a large portion, of which rose from debt issued to buy back our shares. 
Of the interest burden at higher debt level impacts free cash flow, the company's cash flow are benefited by 27% fewer shares outstanding. 
Capital expenditures before special items for the quarter were $344 million, up from $274 million last year, of which 94% of the CapEx invested during the quarter was used for driving increases in new subscriber adds, including increases in Pulse customers and upgrades. 
Direct channel subscriber CapEx increased by 13%, reflecting a 10% increase in gross adds, higher Pulse penetration and Pulse upgrade increasing from 17,000 to 31,000 year-over-year. 
Our dealer channel saw CapEx increased by 33%, attributed to a 19% increase in gross adds, the inclusion of Protectron and significantly higher Pulse take rates. 
Factoring all of these, including the investment in new subscribers, free cash flow before special items for the quarter was $46 million. And as shown on the bottom of the chart, the improvement drivers of our businesses has led to stronger pre-SAC EBITDA resulting in steady-state free cash flow, increasing 14% to $893 million. 
With returns on invested capital on the teams in our subscriber investments, investing in growth make sense for the business and our shareholders. New customers are generating higher ARPU, and we believe will stay with us longer, generating higher future cash flows. 
Some of these investments are transitional such as higher Pulse take rates and Pulse upgrades. These will stabilize the decline over the few years, resulting in sizeable improvement in free cash flows. 
Slide 13 highlights our capital allocation and debt levels for the quarter. On a pro forma basis reflecting a full year for Protectron, leverage was 2.9x at quarter end. Q1 is a historically low cash flow period, and we reported -- repurchased, I'm sorry, 94 million of our shares during the quarter. The company raised $300 million of debt in the quarter, enabling us to pay down a portion of our revolving line of credit. Total debt increased by $158 million from year end. 
Overall, the company's total cost of borrowing was below 4% for the quarter, giving us the flexibility to invest in our business and customer growth, which continues to be the best use of capital for ADT. 
In Q1, we paid a quarterly dividend of $0.20 per share, a 60% increase over last year and announced a 5% increase to our quarterly dividend effective with our next payments. 
We continue to be opportunistic with buying back shares and repurchased 2.9 million shares at an average price of $32.35 during the quarter, bringing the average diluted share count to 175 million. 
We have approximately $286 million remaining on the share buyback authorization, and we remain opportunistic when evaluating future buybacks. 
Now I'd like to turn the call back over to Naren.

componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Over the past year, there has been a lot of questions about ADT's ability to compete against a variety of new companies who've shown interest in the residential security and automation market. 
Over the past several quarters, you were seeing the value of the tremendous assets and capabilities ADT has developed over its 140-year history as a leader in the security industry and our renewed energy and focus since we became an independent company. 
We're excited about our strong start to the year and the progress we are making in achieving our goals for 2015. 
As shown on Slide 14, we're making solid progress towards achieving our goal for the coming year, with both our financial and operational results tracking well to our previously issued guidance. 
Rest assured that we are not resting on our laurels as we understand we need to continue to raise the bar and accelerate our efforts to innovate, grow, become more efficient, and most importantly, enhance the customer experience every day. 
Our entire leadership team is excited about the challenges and opportunities that we see in this incredibly dynamic market, and I remain confident our best days are still ahead of us. 
With that, we'll open up for questions. Benny, can you remind the call participants how they can ask a question?

componenttextpreview: Yes. Jeff, I guess, again, I go up to the pieces of attrition that we believe we can influence. I mean, there's always going to be people moving from 1 household to the next. So we're always going to have disconnects either relocations. As we've discussed
componenttext: Yes. Jeff, I guess, again, I go up to the pieces of attrition that we believe we can influence. I mean, there's always going to be people moving from 1 household to the next. So we're always going to have disconnects either relocations. As we've discussed in the past, our goal was to recapture the house through resales and recapture that customer by doing a very good job of following them. I think we're making good progress there, but that doesn't necessarily impact the gross disconnect piece. The areas we can control is the voluntary and the nonpay. On the nonpay side, clearly, driving the incremental screening that we're doing will result in better quality customers who will stay with us longer and that continuing to drive at the buy very high percentage of our new customers coming on auto pay, some type of easy pay solutions there. So then it's really coming down to the voluntary. And we've got 2 pads that we're pursuing aggressively on that. One is driving the Pulse upgrades because as we talked about on this call and in the past, Pulse had a better attention characteristics because customers armor engaged with their system using it more frequently, and that's why we're pursuing both new Pulse customers, as well as upgrades. And the otherwise is just continuing to improve our service level. It's not as much on the monitoring side. I think when you look at our monitoring and response levels, they are very good. The percentage of calls that we -- the speed at which we answer calls our ability to work through the call list or dispatch immediately in life safety, it's more of the service side, making sure that we're staffed appropriately in our call centers, that we're driving more customers self-service on MyADT.com. So it's a whole portfolio programs that we're driving. And a piece of that is just a culture of transformation. And since we've been an independent company, we've been driving this mindset around customer obsessions and the metrics around customer obsessions in driving more recognition and reward around delivering that great customer experience. So again, I don't know that I can sit here and say what the endgame looks like because some of those other pieces are a little bit out of our control, but we still feel like we've got room ahead of us. We're going to continue to drive it aggressively.

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015

componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our call to discuss ADT's first quarter results for fiscal year 2015. With me on the call today are Naren Gursahaney, ADT's CEO; and Mike Geltzeiler, ADT's CFO. 
Let me begin by reminding everyone that the discussion today contains certain forward-looking statements about the company's future performance, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties and speak only as of today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ from these forward-looking statements are set forth within today's release, which was furnished to the SEC in an 8-K report, and in our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended December 26, 2014, which we expect to file with the SEC later today. 
In our first quarter 2015 earnings release and slides, which are now posted on our website at adt.com and on our Investor Relations app, we have provided a reconciliation of the company's non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP. We urge you to review that information in conjunction with today's discussion. For those of you following on the webcast, we'll be using this slide deck to supplement our commentary this morning. Please note that, unless otherwise mentioned, references to our operating results exclude special items and these metrics are non-GAAP measures. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Naren. Naren?

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. I hope you had a chance to review our earnings press release we issued earlier this morning that highlights our results for the first quarter of 2015. This morning, I'll discus
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. I hope you had a chance to review our earnings press release we issued earlier this morning that highlights our results for the first quarter of 2015. This morning, I'll discuss our key performance highlights and accomplishments for the quarter, then Mike Geltzeiler will provide additional details on our financial and operational performance. 
As you can see from our results, we've continued the trends we saw in the second half of 2014, and we're off to a strong start to the new year, delivering another quarter of improved performance. Solid execution of our initiatives is driving stronger financial and operational results, and the investments we continue to make in our business are positioning us for future profitable revenue growth. All of our key customer metrics continued to move in the right direction during the quarter as we take advantage of our industry-leading position and strong brand recognition. 
We remain excited about what we see in the business today and the evolution occurring in our industry that is creating even more opportunities for future growth. I'm proud of our team's performance this quarter, while recognizing the opportunity for an even brighter future. 
As we review our highlights for the quarter, I think it's important to look at our performance in the context of our strategy and against the backdrop of our rapidly evolving industry. We've made significant progress since becoming a stand-alone company a little over 2 years ago. This progress has accelerated over the past several quarters as we've begun to benefit from the initiatives that we have pursued to enhance our operations and competitive position, resulting in improvements in our performance. 
This quarter, we continue to invest in growth and strengthening our leadership team, all in support of our strategy to achieve our vision for ADT, a vision that's rooted in extending our leadership position in the security, life safety and home automation markets, enhancing the values of ADT's services and executing on our initiatives to drive strong returns. A common thread running throughout every aspect of our vision is creating a superior customer experience. The results from the actions we've taken are continuing to shine through in our results, giving us confidence that we're on the right path. 
As I've discussed on previous calls, I view the recent activity in our industry in 2 distinct areas: integrated professionally monitored security life safety and automation solutions, where ADT is traditionally focused, currently serving about 20% of households; and unmonitored or self-monitored stand-alone home automation solutions, where many new entrants, large and small, are focusing their efforts on the remaining 80% of households. The majority of these efforts are targeting a wide range of home automation applications with only a small portion addressing security and life safety. While our traditional market is more competitive than it was 5 years ago, the environment has been relatively stable, and we're continuing to win in this market, as evidenced by our improving operational and customer metrics and solid financial results. 
Slide 3 shows our strong performance over the past 12 months on 4 key metrics that are affected by the competitive environment. Over the past years, we have driven increases in gross adds in all lines of business and in our direct and dealer channels, improved customer retention by 120 basis points, increased the average price paid by newly added customers and reduced our creation multiple, or in other words, the cost we incur to bring on a new customer. I think this chart is the best evidence that we are winning in the market and our performance is accelerating. 
Specifically, for the first quarter, as highlighted on Slide 4, we drove double-digit gross subscriber growth with year-over-year increases in both our direct and authorized dealer channels for the first time since 2013, driven by stronger lead generation, increases in our self-generated business and improved close rates. Unit and revenue attrition continue to improve meaningfully versus prior year and sequentially as we reduced attrition to its lowest level since we became a public company. As a result of these improvements in gross adds and customer retention, we narrowed our net subscriber loss significantly and are focused on returning to growing net subscribers. From a financial perspective, our improved operational performance allowed us to deliver strong recurring revenue growth, increased EBITDA margins and bottom line results on a year-over-year basis. 
Because of the strong returns we drive in our business today and the many opportunities we see to generate profitable growth in the years ahead, we continue to invest in ADT's future, as shown on Slide 5. 
We're investing to enhance the customer experience by implementing new technologies and processes, including the rollout of a new electronic order management platform and the deployment of our new wireless Total Security panel. We're expanding our presence in the midsize commercial market and making investments in products and distribution to generate future growth through our health service offerings. We also added a new key leader to run our combined business in Canada and appointed a new Board member from the technology sector, Chris Hylen of Citrix Systems. 
We're also continuing to invest in driving profitable growth through Pulse. Pulse continues to be an important driver behind our results. And in Q1, Pulse take rates increased as did Pulse upgrades. 
As you can see on Slide 6, over 53% of our total gross adds during the quarter were Pulse units, up from 51% last quarter and 37% a year ago. In our residential direct channel, the Pulse take rate for new and resale units was nearly 57%, up 15 percentage points over the same quarter last year. And 71% of all new residential customers added via our direct sales channel were Pulse customers. 
In our small business channel, the Pulse take rate was 50%, up 14 percentage points over the first quarter of last year. In our dealer channel, the Pulse take rate ramped to 50% from about 40% -- 47% last quarter and 29% last year. 
In addition to new system sales of Pulse, we upgraded about 31,000 existing customers this quarter. This is nearly double the number we did in the same period last year. Our Pulse upgrade efforts allow us to provide additional functionality to our existing customers and yield higher ARPU. 
In addition, these upgrades allow us to enter into new contracts with these customers and enhance the customer experience. I'm happy with the progress we're making in our operations and with the investments that we're making in our future. 
Before turn I turn the call over to Mike, I want to share some of my thoughts on the evolving landscape in our industry and some observations from the Consumer Electronics Show that took place earlier this month. 
At CES this year, the connected home and Internet of Things continue to gain significant traction. In fact, there was an entire venue dedicated to the connected home and IoT innovations, where ADT was well represented and traffic was very robust. The conference showcased several new technology companies, along with many of the biggest names in the consumer electronics industry, offering point solutions for the connected world and smart home. 
ADT's prominent presence at the event featured several of our products with a primary focus on Pulse. In fact, Pulse was recognized by Time Magazine as one of the 6 coolest smart home innovations at the show. 
Pulse was also featured in a CES keynote address by Brian Krzanich, the CEO of Intel, who demonstrated the integration of Pulse with Intel Securities' True Key multifactor authentication to provide a new level of security and convenience for users. This jointly developed proof of concept was hailed by Brian as an example of how our IoT partnership can make a smart home also a safe home. At CES, we also showcased our new Total Security wireless panel for Pulse automation installations, which we rolled out last quarter and installed approximately 8,000 units during the quarter.  
What I saw at CES this year reinforced several thoughts on ADT's positioning for the future. First, much of the product innovation and many new point solutions are geared towards the 80% of the market, not reached or targeted by traditional professional installed and monitored security and automation solutions. The growing interest in this segment is raising the awareness of and the growth opportunity for monitored security and home automation. 
Second, these self-monitored smart home solutions are not necessarily creating a safe home, as notifying and seeing are not the same as monitoring. Additionally, customers are growing wary of the large and growing number of apps needed to manage all the disparate devices in their home. Most customers prefer to have a single platform with an easy and unified customer experience to manage their connected home. 
Finally, a primary driver of consumer interest in smart home applications is security. This was reinforced by recent research conducted by several third parties, including Lowe's and the Consumer Electronics Association. I believe ADT is well positioned to capture additional growth in the future given our large customer base, trusted brand, robust monitoring infrastructure, strong field sales and installation force and fully developed Pulse platform. ADT is viewed as a partner of choice by many well-respected companies in the industry. I believe that ADT is in the right place, at the right time, with the right platform, services and products to capitalize on this opportunity to make homes and businesses both smart and safe. 
Now let me turn things over to Mike to provide some additional details on our financial and operational performance during the quarter.

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Naren. As Naren mentioned, we're off to a strong start this year, delivering another quarter of improved financial and operational results. The metrics that drive our business are moving in the right direction, and we continue to invest in new gro
componenttext:
Thanks, Naren. As Naren mentioned, we're off to a strong start this year, delivering another quarter of improved financial and operational results. The metrics that drive our business are moving in the right direction, and we continue to invest in new growth opportunities in health and commercial security. We're working diligently on improving our customers' experience. 
While we're committed to delivering improved financial performance, as evidenced by the strong start to the year, we have an ambitious plan to invest and build on these results to create a better ADT for both our customers and shareholders. This includes investing to improve customer experience, automating and streamlining processes, opening our platform to partners, expanding our services and distribution and integrating our Canadian businesses. Over the next few slides, I'll review our Q1 performance and highlight our accomplishments during the quarter. 
Slide 8 provides an overview of our GAAP and non-GAAP results. Recurring revenue grew 6.5% to $825 million and accounted for 93% of our total revenue. Our total revenue rose 5.7%. When adjusting for the decline in the Canadian dollar, recurring revenue was up over 7% and total revenue increased by 6.4%. We remain focused on growing our business through a highly profitable recurring revenue model, continuing the trend you have seen in our historical results. 
We continue to integrate Protectron into our results as we recognized a full quarter of contribution in Q1. Protectron contributed over half of the recurring revenue growth in the period, but since it currently operates at a lower margin than the ADT business, the consolidation had a dilutive impact to EBITDA margins, increased our D&A and was neutral on EPS. 
EBITDA before special items for the quarter was $453 million, up 6% or $27 million over prior year. The weak Canadian dollar diluted this growth by $1.5 million. This translated to an EBITDA margin of 51.1%, an increase of 30 basis points year-over-year. Excluding the dilutive impact of Protectron, EBITDA margins before special items increased by nearly 100 basis points from last year. Year-over-year, recurring revenue growth, combined with our cost efficiency initiative, drove the increase in our margins. 
Cost to serve was up 6% due primarily to the consolidation of Protectron. However, without Protectron, cost-to-serve expenses were flat with last year despite a higher mix of Pulse subscribers, additional investments in customer experience and launching our commercial business. 
GAAP EPS was $0.41 a share, which includes special items and a tax rate in the quarter of 33.3%. Excluding special items, non-GAAP diluted EPS was $0.51, up 19% from Q1 2014. Using our Q1 tax cash tax rate of 4.6%, our earnings per share before special items was $0.73 for the quarter, up 11% over last year. 
The chart also details our special items for the quarter. In Q1, we accelerated the conversion of 2G radio customers, successfully converting 113,000 customers, a portion of which we were able to up-sell to ADT Pulse. We also incurred a minor level of integration expenses related to Protectron acquisition as well as some restructuring charges. 
Activity to integrate Protectron will accelerate following the recent appointment of a new President for our combined Canadian operations. Our 2G conversion program will continue through 2016. We are comfortably ahead of plan and are opportunistically balancing this program against resource availability and customer demand. 
Turning to the operating levers. Slide 9 shows strong gross add growth and increases in average revenue per unit for Q1 versus the prior year. Total company gross adds increased over 13% year-over-year, driven by improved performance in our direct and dealer channels as well as across our residential business and health units. 
Gross adds in our direct channel were up 10%, marking the first time we've experienced year-over-year growth since 2013. The increase in gross additions was due to stronger lead generation, higher close rates and greater self-generated sales. Protectron accounted for about 20% of the growth rate in the direct channel. 
New subscriber growth was accomplished despite the headwinds caused by our fully implemented enhanced credit screening procedures, which management estimates filtered out about 4,000 potential sales. We expect this enhanced processed to improve further -- future attrition by filtering credit-challenged customers into different payment plans, which allows us to focus on profitable growth. 
Gross adds in our dealer channel rose 19% from last year as we experienced higher sales from existing dealers, added some new dealers and benefited from the dealer volume production of Protectron. Returning dealer volumes to growth was a 2014 priority, which we accomplished in Q4. We are very pleased with our partners, delivering 100,000 customer adds for Q1, a 16,000 increase over Q1 2014. 
Our ability to grow ARPU shows that pricing remains healthy in our business. Our continued investment in ADT Pulse, combined with incremental service offerings, like small business bundles and hosted video, have helped drive higher revenue per user. 
For the quarter, new and resale ARPU was $47.28, an increase of 5% over the prior year, and ARPU for our overall customer base was $41.76, an increase of 2% year-over-year. As a reminder, Protectron generates lower ARPU than our traditional base in the U.S., which diluted the overall year-over-year growth figure as did the weaker Canadian dollar. Excluding Protectron, ARPU rose 4% over last year. 
Over the course of the last year, we launched a number of initiatives designed to improve the customer experience and increase customer retention. Our results on Slide 10 show that these initiatives are paying off as we improve attrition for the third consecutive quarter and reduce it to its lowest level since becoming a public company. 
Q1 trailing 12-month net revenue attrition was 13.0%, a sequential improvement of 50 basis points and a significant reduction of 120 basis points versus Q1 prior year. Unit attrition, which measures customer attrition for just our residential and business customers, was 12.9% for the quarter, a 30-basis-point improvement versus Q4 and 70 basis points lower than last year. Our focus on enhancing the customer experience, reducing non-pay disconnections and increasing resales, coupled with stable existing home sales, contributed to lower attrition. 
The key to driving higher recurring revenues is increasing average revenue per customer through new offerings, greater automation and price escalations, all of which we are executing well as well as growing the subscriber base. For the past 2 years, we have grown our subscriber base primarily as a result of M&A. Organically, we reported a net subscriber loss of over 100,000 customers in 2014. As we progress our dual goals of growing gross adds and lowering attrition, we are positioning the company towards its ultimate objective of organic net subscriber growth. 
In the first quarter, we reported a decline in our customer base of 8,000 subscribers. However, this compares favorably to Q1 2014, where we lost 48,000 customers. This is a major step forward and bodes well for future revenue growth. 
Slide 11 shows recurring revenue margin and SAC. For the quarter, recurring revenue margin on our existing customer base was 66.4%, up 10 basis points versus prior year. The current quarter included investments in our commercial expansion and health business, the dilutive effect of consolidating Protectron and inefficiencies from the Tyco separation. Excluding Protectron, recurring revenue margins would have been 67%, an increase of 70 basis points. As I mentioned earlier, cost-to-serve expense is flat with last year on higher revenues. 
We continue to make progress in driving down customer acquisition costs and lowering our overall net creation multiple despite higher Pulse take rates, which require a larger upfront investment. Excluding the impact of Pulse upgrades, our combined net creation multiple improved by 0.7x to 31.7 in Q1, while the net creation multiple in our direct channel fell to 31.9x, a 2.1x improvement from last year. As a reminder, the first quarter has historically been our highest level of SAC mostly due to absorption issues, and it's the lowest quarter of volumes. 
Average net SAC, excluding upgrades for our direct channel, was about $,1,500 per unit, which was actually below the same figure last year despite the increased sales of more expensive Pulse and automation units. This was possible because of productivity improvements, marketing savings and hardware efficiencies. 
In the quarter, we began deploying our new Total Security panel for new Pulse automation customers, continued our implementation of electronic contracts and delivered on our cost efficiency programs. ADT Business has now rolled out eContracts nationally and resi will do the same in February. 
As mentioned earlier, we are investing in our business, in customer growth, Pulse, commercial expansion, health and customer experience, all in order to build a stronger and more profitable subscriber base. On Slide 12, we detail the components of free cash flow for the quarter. Cash flow from operations, before special items, was up 14% from last year to $390 million. The increase in operating cash flow is driven by past investments, our improved financial and operational performance in the quarter and improvements in working capital management. This 14% growth is despite a $25 million year-over-year increase in cash interest expense, a large portion of which arose from debt issued to buy back our shares. While the interest burden at higher debt levels impact free cash flow, the company's cash flows are benefited by 27% fewer shares outstanding. 
Capital expenditures before special items for the quarter were $344 million, up from $274 million last year, of which 94% of the CapEx invested during the quarter was used for driving increases in new subscriber adds, including increases in Pulse customers and upgrades. Direct channel subscriber CapEx increased by 13%, reflecting a 10% increase in gross adds, higher Pulse penetration and Pulse upgrade increasing from 17,000 to 31,000 year-over-year. Our dealer channel saw CapEx increase by 33%, attributed to a 19% increase in gross adds, the inclusion of Protectron and significantly higher Pulse take rates. 
Factoring all of these, including the investment in new subscribers, free cash flow before special items for the quarter was $46 million. And as shown at the bottom of the chart, the improvement in the drivers of our businesses has led to stronger pre-SAC EBITDA, resulting in steady-state free cash flow increasing 14% to $893 million. 
With returns on invested capital in the teens on our subscriber investments, investing in growth makes sense for the business and our shareholders. New customers are generating higher ARPU, and we believe will stay with us longer, generating higher future cash flows. Some of these investments are transitional, such as higher Pulse take rates and Pulse upgrades. These will stabilize in decline over the few years, resulting in sizeable improvement in free cash flows. 
Slide 13 highlights our capital allocation and debt levels for the quarter. On a pro forma basis reflecting a full year for Protectron, leverage was 2.9x at quarter end. Q1 is a historically low cash flow period, and we reported -- repurchased, I'm sorry, 94 million of our shares during the quarter. The company raised $300 million of debt in the quarter, enabling us to pay down a portion of our revolving line of credit. Total debt increased by $158 million from year end. Overall, the company's total cost of borrowing was below 4% for the quarter, giving us the flexibility to invest in our business and customer growth, which continues to be the best use of capital for ADT. 
In Q1, we paid a quarterly dividend of $0.20 per share, a 60% increase over last year, and announced a 5% increase to our quarterly dividend effective with our next payments. We continue to be opportunistic when buying back shares and repurchased 2.9 million shares at an average price of $32.35 during the quarter, bringing the average diluted share count to 175 million. We have approximately $286 million remaining on the share buyback authorization, and we remain opportunistic when evaluating future buybacks. 
Now I'd like to turn the call back over to Naren.

componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Over the past year, there have been a lot of questions about ADT's ability to compete against a variety of new companies who have shown interest in the residential security and automation market. Over the past several quarters, you were seeing the value of the tremendous assets and capabilities ADT has developed over its 140-year history as a leader in the security industry and our renewed energy and focus since we became an independent company. We're excited about our strong start to the year and the progress we are making in achieving our goals for 2015. 
As shown on Slide 14, we're making solid progress towards achieving our goal for the coming year, with both our financial and operational results tracking well to our previously issued guidance. Rest assured that we are not resting on our laurels as we understand we need to continue to raise the bar and accelerate our efforts to innovate, grow, become more efficient, and most importantly, enhance the customer experience every day. Our entire leadership team is excited about the challenges and the opportunities that we see in this incredibly dynamic market, and I remain confident our best days are still ahead of us. 
With that, we'll open up for questions. Benny, can you remind the call participants how they can ask a question?

componenttext: Well, Ian, clearly, this is one of our top priorities as an organization, and it ties to both of our initiatives: Our continued drive to increase gross adds in all of our channels and all of our lines of business; and two, is to continue to drive improvements in unit and revenue attrition. But this would clearly be more tied to the unit attrition. I hesitate to pick a specific quarter because you do get seasonality, both on the gross adds side as well on the disconnect side. So all I would say is that we're continuing to drive towards that. As you saw in the first quarter, we narrowed that gap dramatically and I think the trends in both gross adds and in attrition, unit attrition are very favorable. And I feel confident we're going to continue to move in the right direction there.

We've been very careful in evaluating bulk purchases. Some of those do result in future attrition, but I think to be able to sort of get that balanced organically, which is our goal, I think would be industry leading.

componenttext: Yes. Well, again, Charlie, remember we're 4 years into Pulse versus what we know on our traditional. It is many, many years of those life in curves [ph]. So I hate to -- I hesitate to draw any firm conclusions at this stage. I think we can clearly say that in aggregate, Pulse customer retention is better than what we see on traditional, and that's specifically true as we get into the automation side. We just see better engagement of those customers and what they use. So we're continuing to focus, not just on driving Pulse, but driving more Pulse customers up to that high end. It still represents less than 20% of our base today despite all the work we've done, both on new adds, where we're seeing great traction and even with the upgrades. So I still think there's plenty of incremental opportunity and we're going to continue to be aggressive, both on gross adds and in driving Pulse upgrades to the base.

Sure. I mean, I think we -- look, the first quarter of last year was not a strong quarter for SAC, but what we did indicate was it was also our lowest quarter for volumes. And there is an absorption issue in our business. When we take the cost in the organization that focuses on installing systems, that is part of SAC, so it's not a pure variable cost that's being allocated. We talked about rolling out the TS panel. We only rolled out 8,000 of our 260,000 adds this quarter. We're on TS, okay? That's going to accelerate and that, as we identified, had labor savings. 
I talked about the eContracts. We really just started to roll that out into small biz or into biz. And now it's being rolled out in the second quarter into resi as well. There's efficiencies there. We have other hardware and peripherals savings, too.

componenttext: There's a lot of debate as to what the ultimate ceiling on ARPU can be for a company -- for companies in this business. componenttextpreview: Yes. Jeff, I guess, again, I go to the pieces of attrition that we believe we can influence. I mean, there's always going to be people moving from one household to the next. So we're always going to have disconnects tied to relocations. As we've discussed
componenttext:
Yes. Jeff, I guess, again, I go to the pieces of attrition that we believe we can influence. I mean, there's always going to be people moving from one household to the next. So we're always going to have disconnects tied to relocations. As we've discussed in the past, our goal was to recapture the house through resales and recapture that customer by doing a better job of following them. I think we're making good progress there, but that doesn't necessarily impact the gross disconnect piece. 
The areas we can control is the voluntary and the non-pay. On the non-pay side, clearly, driving the incremental screening that we're doing will result in better quality customers who will stay with us longer, and then continuing to drive where a very high percentage of our new customers coming on auto pay or some type of easy pay solution there. 
So then it really comes down to the voluntary. And we've got 2 paths that we're pursuing aggressively on that. One is driving the Pulse upgrades, because as we talked about on this call and in the past, Pulse had better attention characteristics because customers are more engaged with their system, using it more frequently. And that's why we're pursuing both new Pulse customers as well as upgrades. And the other one is just continuing to improve our service levels. 
It's not as much on the monitoring side. I think when you look at our monitoring and response levels, they are very good: we -- the percentage of calls that we -- the speed at which we answer calls, our ability to work through the call list or dispatch immediately in life safety. It's more on the service side, making sure that we're staffed appropriately in our call centers, that are -- we're driving more customer self service on myadt.com. So it's a whole portfolio of programs that we're driving. 
And a piece of that is just a cultural transformation. And since we've been an independent company, we've been driving this mindset around customer obsessions and the metrics around customer obsessions and driving more recognition and reward around delivering that great customer experience. So again, I don't know that I can sit here and say what the endgame looks like, because some of those other pieces are a little bit out of our control. But we still feel like we've got room ahead of us and we're going to continue to drive it aggressively.

Some of them have issued reports that certainly allow our leverage to go above where we're at today. I think it's important to know, our 3x is not a cap. It's our long-term policy. If, for some reason, we went above 3x for the right strategic reasons, we would lever ourselves back down to 3x, as 3x is our goal. And so -- but I think the bondholders are important constituents of ours as well, and so I think the BB commitment that we're most focused on in right now. And our financial policy isn't changing and 3x is our sort of what we think the appropriate target leverage for this firm.
