headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie, and good morning, and thank you for joining us for our call to discuss ADT's fourth quarter and full year results for fiscal 2015. With me on the call today are Naren Gursahaney, ADT's CEO; and Mike Geltzeiler, ADT's CFO. Let me
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie, and good morning, and thank you for joining us for our call to discuss ADT's fourth quarter and full year results for fiscal 2015. 
With me on the call today are Naren Gursahaney, ADT's CEO; and Mike Geltzeiler, ADT's CFO. 
Let me begin by reminding everyone that the discussion today contain certain forward-looking statements about the company's future performance, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties and speak only as of today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ from these forward-looking statements are set forth within today's earnings release, which is furnished to the SEC in an 8-K report and in our Form 10-K for the year ended September 25, 2015, which we expect to file with the SEC later this week. 
In our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings release and slides, which are now posted on our website at adt.com and on our Investor Relations app, we have provided a reconciliation of the company's non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP. We urge you to review that information in conjunction with today's call. 
For those of you following us on the webcast, we will be using the slide deck to supplement our commentary this morning. Please note that unless otherwise mentioned, references to our operating results exclude special items, and these metrics are non-GAAP financial metrics. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Naren. Naren?

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. We hope you had a chance to review our previously issued earnings press release that highlights our results for the fourth quarter and our full fiscal year 2015. This morning
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. We hope you had a chance to review our previously issued earnings press release that highlights our results for the fourth quarter and our full fiscal year 2015. 
This morning, I will discuss our key performance highlights and accomplishments for the quarter and year, than our CFO, Mike Geltzeiler, will provide additional details on our financial and operational performance as well as our outlook for 2016. 
2015 was a pivotal year for ADT. We met or exceeded all of our major financial and operational goals and made further progress towards building a foundation for future profitable growth. 
Our continued focus on customer retention and quality growth resulted in our key metric moving in the right direction again in the fourth quarter, reinforcing that we're pursuing the right strategies and priorities. 
We continue to make smart investments in our business and establish new partnerships, positioning us well to execute upon our growth strategies. Many of the initiatives that fueled our performance in 2015 were launched in 2014 when we refocused our organization on improving customer retention by enhancing all aspects of the customer experience, attracting high-quality new customers in both our direct and dealer channels, selectively expanding into adjacent markets and exploring opportunities previously underpenetrated markets. 
As a result of our team's improved execution, the impact of these efforts first began to show through in our improved performance in the second half of 2014 and have continued to carry through in our results this past year.  We're proud of what we've accomplished and remain confident that our best years are still in front of us. 
The next 3 slides in the presentation deck reflect our report card for 2015. 
I'll begin with the key operating levers that drive our results. Slide 3 shows our performance over the past year on the 4 operating levers that are affected by the competitive environment. 
As you can see, we've delivered strong improvements in all 4 of these important levers. We increased gross adds across all lines of business and channels, improved customer retention by 130 basis points, increased new and resale ARPU by nearly 4% and reduced our direct channel creation multiple, which reflects the cash payback period for newly generated accounts. 
This chart is evidence that we remain competitively strong and are extending our market leadership position, while improving overall business performance. 
These operating lovers fueled our improved performance in 2015. As shown on Slide 4, which highlight some of our key accomplishments, we delivered solid recurring revenue growth and improved financial results throughout the year. Customer adds increased by more than 6% over last year despite enhanced customer screening and other new customer onboarding requirements. 
We also focused a portion of our sales and marketing activities on Pulse upgrades, which rose 63% for the year. 
Operationally, our primary focus continues to be on improved customer retention. For the year, we reduced attrition significantly, closing the year at 12.2% unit and revenue attrition, which is the lowest we have seen since the spin. This helped us reduce customer losses in 2015 and positions us well for net that growth in the future. 
We also further reduced the cost of adding new customers to the ADT family, resulting in our lowest creation multiples since we became a public company despite a steady increase in Pulse take rates. 
And speaking of Pulse, we increased total Pulse customers by 50% during the year, reaching 1.5 million customers. 
As I stated previously, Pulse was a standalone company, it would be the second largest residential security company in North America, only behind ADT. 
On the strategic front, we further strengthened our competitive position and paved the way for future profitable growth by expanding into new market segments and entering into key partnerships to improve our product portfolio. 
This year, we launched ADT Business, supporting our expansion in the small business channel and entry into the mid-sized commercial market. 
Our business channel delivered double-digit year-over-year new customer growth this year, and we're still in the early stages of our commercial expansion. 
We also enhanced our health business with the launch of our mobile PERS solution with full detection and added new distribution channels. 
We've opened up our Pulse ecosystem and partnered with innovative companies like Nest Labs to allow ADT customers to integrate with best-of-breed product like the Nest Learning Thermostat. 
After successful launch in 4 pilot markets, we're now making this integration available for our Pulse automation customers nationwide. 
We also launched the new ADT owned Pulse mobile app with more intuitive and easier navigation for our Pulse customers. 
And lastly, I n collaboration with LG, we announced a new all-in-one security device with ADT monitoring services to target the unpenetrated North American residential market, including renters and frequent movers. 
We've made significant progress on the product, associated services and retail distribution strategy, and we are now targeting the first calendar quarter of 2016 for our launch. We're very excited about what this means for our business in the future. 
On Slide #5, you can see our overall performance was strong as we met or exceeded our guidance for 2015 on a constant-currency basis. 
And on Slide #6, you can see some of our achievements for the fourth quarter. Mike will cover the quarter in greater detail, but I wanted to mention a couple items. 
Overall, our operating metrics continued to move in the right direction, highlighted by another drop in net unit attrition, which improved 100 basis points year-over-year and net revenue attrition, which improved 130 basis points from last year. Both ended the year at 12.2%. 
We generated 278,000 gross adds, about flat with prior year, excluding both account purchases as we continue to focus on quality customer additions that will provide longer tenure and higher financial returns. 
These strong operating metrics fueled growth in revenues, EBITDA and free cash flow on a year-over-year basis. 
Although we've shared Slide #7 before, I want to spend a minute on our strategy to create shareholder value as, I think, this reflects our strategic priorities very well. Our strategy is focused on 3 areas: Growing our traditional business, selectively expanding it to near adjacencies and partnering that to target the nontraditional residential market. 
The dynamic in the industry continues to be positive creating a tremendous opportunity for ADT. A key driver of our opportunity continues to be growing consumer interest in smart home and Internet of Things devices, along with their desire to be in control and safe and security remains at the top of the list of reasons for this consumer interest, which is great news for ADT. These changing market dynamics in the residential market, combined with the investments we're making in commercial and health, resulted in very large market opportunity for ADT. 
In total, we expect our addressable market to nearly triple over the next 5 years to over 70 billion potential customers. 
We're coupling this growth activities with our strong balance sheet and are focused on optimizing our capital structure and capital allocation. We continue to reinvest cash to support this organic growth, remain disciplined in our strategic M&A activities and are returning excess capital to our shareholders via dividends and opportunistic share buybacks. 
At the heart of our strategy is our focus on customer retention. As shown on Slide 8, we are continuing to strengthen and refine our focus on improving customer retention by doing 3 basic things: One, bringing on the right customer; two, onboarding them in the right way; and three, providing them a great customer experience. 
Doing these 3 things right is the key to further reductions in attrition and the right formula for improving customer economics and generating higher free cash flow. 
We've made much progress over the past 2 years in improving these areas, which is why we've seen a significant improvements in retention and net add performance. However, with new tools and analytics now at our disposal giving us better insights for the customer behavior and tendencies, we will make further improvements in the future. 
We started last year with enhanced tenure screening to target higher quality customers upfront before we spend money to add them into our network. This effort alone is still nearly 16,000 potential customer adds in the year and has contributed to a significant drop in attrition in the non-pay category. 
With the additional insights into customer behavior and the new tools such as our electronic order management platform, we are continuing to refine our approach and putting in place new customer requirements that will result in more engaged and longer tenured customers. 
Improving the customer experience is at the core of our strategy and Pulse customers continue to exhibit better economics and retention. 
On Slide #9, you can see that over 59% of our total gross adds during the quarter were Pulse units, up from 51% a year ago. 
In our residential direct channel, the Pulse take rate for new and resale units was 65% or more than 75% of all new residential customers added via this channel were Pulse customers. 
In our dealer channel, the Pulse take rate ramped up to 57% from about 47% last year and in our small business channel, the Pulse take rate was 41%. 
In addition to new Pulse sales, we also upgraded about 39,000 existing customers this quarter. Pulse upgrades allow us to provide additional service to our existing customers and yield higher RPU. 
In addition, these upgrades allow us to enhance the customer experience and enter into new contracts. We now have approximately 1.5 million Pulse customers with total interactive customers now comp -- comprising about 23% of our customer base. 
As we discussed during our Investor Day, Pulse customers continue to demonstrate better retention characteristics than traditional security customers. 
Our analysis also shows that retention further improves when customers choose automation features such as thermostats, light switches, door lock and cameras. 
Equally as important, our initial data also shows that the resale rate, the rate at which we sign up a new customer who moves into a home where Pulse automation is already installed is higher as compared to non-Pulse customers. 
Now let me turn things over to Mike to provide some additional details and financial and operational performance for the quarter and the year.

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Naren. 2015 a was transitional year for ADT, which we improved both our operational and financial performance, positioning the company for future growth and increased profitability. In our core operations, this means a disciplined, more acute fo
componenttext:
Thanks, Naren. 2015 a was transitional year for ADT, which we improved both our operational and financial performance, positioning the company for future growth and increased profitability. 
In our core operations, this means a disciplined, more acute focus on customer economics and return on invested capital. Hence, the term smart growth, quality growth and profitable growth describing our business objectives. 
As Naren said, by enhancing the customer experience and using data analytics to drive our customer acquisition practices, we believe we can attract the right customers with the right offerings and the appropriate SAC, and ensure that these customers remain with us longer. This approach does put some topline pressure on gross ad growth with a dividend and customer retention, lower SAC, higher margins and increased free cash flow. As we look ahead to 2016, we expect more to stay. I will discuss 2016 guidance later in my remarks. 
First, I'll review our Q4 and full year performance. Slide 10 summarizes our GAAP and non-GAAP financial results for the quarter. In Q4, recurring revenue, which accounts for approximately 93% of our total revenue, grew 2% to $835 million and total revenue increased by 1.8% to $899 million. 
Recurring revenue growth outpaced total revenue growth as we continue to add different products and services to our portfolio that generate recurring revenue in place of lower-margin onetime sales. 
For example, late in 2014, our business channel began to offer hosted video services that generate recurring revenue in place of onetime DVR sales. 
All this being said, in 2016, we will have the opportunity to grow nonrecurring revenue as our commercial channel continue to gain traction, and we broadened our service capabilities and product offerings. 
When adjusting for the Canadian dollar, which impacts approximately 10% of our total revenues and has declined significantly versus prior year, recurring revenue was up 3.4% and total revenue increased by 3.3%. 
In Q4, we put operating expenses before special items were up 3.9% over the last year, including a 5% increase in depreciation and amortization. 
Excluding the $8 million impact of the marketing efficiency program, total operating expense before special items were up just 2.7% in the quarter. 
Besides depreciation, the increased total expenses was driven by the growth of Pulse, investments in our commercial expansion and development of our new Pulse app and all in one DIY product as well as investments we have made to improve our service levels. 
EBITDA before special items was $460 million, which includes a negative impact of approximately $8 million related to the previously disclosed change in the way we account for our marketing efficiency program as well as a negative impact of approximately $5 million due to the decline in Canadian dollar. 
Adjusting for these 2 items, EBITDA was $50 million favorable to the prior year. EBITDA margin for the quarter was 51.2%, 100 basis point improvement from Q3.  Improvement reflects continued execution of our cost efficiency program. 
Excluding special items, non-GAAP diluted EPS was $0.51, which includes the impact of $0.03 per share related to the prior mentioned marketing efficiency program. This compares to non-GAAP diluted EPS of $0.55 per share last year. 
Using our Q4 cash tax rate, diluted earnings per share before special items was $0.73 for the quarter. Our effective tax rate was 30.8% compared with 24.8% last year. 
Slide 10 also details our special items for the quarter. In Q4, we continue to make progress on our 2G radio conversion program, upgrading or converting nearly 40,000 customers in the quarter for a total of approximately 276,000 for the year. 
We have made significant progress since we started this project and have about 500,000 customers left we either need to upgrade or convert into new radio. We plan to complete most of these conversions in fiscal 2016 and finalize the program in our first quarter of fiscal 2017. 
Turning to the operating levers. Slide 11 shows gross adds and average revenue per unit for Q4. Overall, total company gross adds, excluding Pulse acquisitions were 278,000, the highest level of 2015 of flat versus last year. 
Our company's focused on quality growth combined with enhanced tenure screening created some slight headwinds to overall year-over-year growth but resulted in better financial results. Gross adds in our direct channel were up slightly, offset by dealer gross addition, which were nearly flat last year. 
Gross adds for ADT Business were up 17% and health adds were higher by 27%. 
Pricing continue to be an area of strength as both average and new and resale ARPU continue to grow in the fourth quarter. 
Overall, pricing remains healthy in our business as we continue to drive higher Pulse take rates with greater automation and grow our business channel, which has the higher ARPU. 
For the quarter, new and resale ARPU was $48.40, an increase of 3.4% over the prior year. Our RPU for the overall customer base was $42.65, an increase of nearly 3% year-over-year. 
When adjusting for the Canadian FX, RPU was up by 4% over last year. 
As I indicated earlier, the company is committed to pursuing profitable growth and enhancing customer expense, which leads to greater customer retention and loyalty. Slide 12 shows the progress we've made on customer retention. Attrition has improved for 6 consecutive quarters, reaching a new low in Q4. Net revenue attrition was 12.2%, sequential improvement of 20 basis points and a significant reduction of 130 basis points versus last year. Unit attrition, which measures customer attrition for just our residential and business customers, was also 12.2% for the quarter and 10 basis point improvement versus Q3 and 100 basis points lower than last year. 
Improvements was led by the progress we've made in gross attrition throughout 2015 as we reduced non-pay voluntary and lost the competition disconnection, combined with a 21% year-over-year increase in resales. 
Relocations skewed higher this quarter is the housing market improved but this is more than offset by attrition improvement elsewhere and by the higher resales. 
We are pleased with the progress we've made this year as our attrition results are materially favorable to both our guidance and prior year results. However, we see ample opportunity to perform better and are targeting further improvement in 2016. 
Slide 13 shows our quarterly results for recurring revenue margin and SAC creation multiples. For the quarter, recurring revenue margin in our existing customer base was about 66.6% compared to 67.5% in last year. And the recurring revenue margin is down versus last year, it increased sequentially by 70 basis points in Q4. 
Margins throughout the year have been pressured by our investments to expand into commercial, development of our new Pulse app and costs associated with the launch of our all in 1 DIY product. 
Additionally, increased spending to improve customer service levels and respond times have negatively impacted margins but contributed to improvements in customer experience and attrition. 
SAC is another favorable story for 2015. We've consistently lowered SAC in 2015 through marketing efficiencies, sales effectiveness and the installation processes by implementing electronic contracts, Total Security panel and lower cost equipment. 
Our combined net creation multiple improved by 0.8x to 29.8x in Q4, while the net creation multiple in our direct channel fell to 29.1x, a onetime improvement versus last year. 
Net SAC in our direct channel fell to nearly $1,400, below the average SAC levels in Q4 2014. 
We have lowered both total and direct channel creation multiples, excluding upgrade in every quarter this year, while also increasing Pulse take rates. 
Slide 14 details the components of our fourth quarter free cash flow results. The charts aggregate cash flow into cash generated from existing customers and cash invested to secure a newer upgrading system customers. 
Free cash flow before special items was $77 million in Q4, up $23 million or 43% versus last year. It's the second consecutive quarter of free cash flow growth, enabling us to finish 2015 with free cash flow before special items of $321 million, which is about 30% higher than the 2015 figure we baselined at our Investor Day in May. 
Pre-SAC free cash flow before special items was driven by lower attrition, operational improvements and growth in Pulse customers. 
For the quarter, pre-SAC free cash flow before special items increased by 5.6% to $510 million, up $27 million from last year. 
Investing in new customer growth is the main driver behind our ability to generate feature free cash flow and our quality growth initiatives enable us to focus on the customers, which we feel are most likely to meet our return criteria. 
Total SAC before special items for the quarter was $433 million, marginally above the $429 million in Q4 last year. 
For the year, free cash flow from our existing customers increased $116 million to almost $2 billion. This was partially offset by a $1.7 billion investment in new customers. 
This investment represents an increase of about 8%, driven by a 6% growth in gross adds and about 50,000 more Pulse upgrades. 
Slide 15 highlights the improvements we've made in our steady-state free cash flow results over last year. Steady-state free cash flow is a long-term valuation metric, which allows us to measure the free cash flow, generated by maintaining the recurring revenue from our existing customer base before investing in new subscriber growth. 
The key drivers to this symmetric, pre-SAC EBITDA, SAC creation multiples and attrition are all continuing to move in the right direction, which allowed us to improve our results over last year. 
Steady-state free cash flow before special items was $996 million, up $30 million versus prior year. When analyzing results in constant currency, steady-state free cash flow exceeded our guidance of $1 billion. 
Slide 16 highlights our capital allocation and debt levels for the quarter. Trailing 12-month leverage reached 3x EBITDA, and trailing 12 months debt to pre-SAC EBITDA was 2.4x. 
As a reminder, we began reporting pre-SAC leverage ratio to provide a harmonized view similar to how most if not all our security competitors report leverage by removing the expense investment in new subscribers. 
In addition, our EBITDA results were negatively impacted by about $25 million in 2015 as a result of the noncash change on how we report the marketing efficiency program. Our long-term leverage target remains 3x EBITDA. 
Our total cost of borrowing was below 4% in Q4 and our debt continues to trade at favorable levels. Having a low cost of borrowing provides us the flexibility to invest in growth and return capital to our shareholders. 
In the fourth quarter, we paid a quarterly dividend of $0.21 per share or 5% increase over last year. 
In Q4, we also repurchased 4.3 million shares at an average price of $32.70 per share, contributing to the total of 9.8 million shares for $324 million of repurchases for fiscal 2015. 
With our cash flow increasing, our business payable and our growth initiatives adequately funded, we continue to view share repurchases at current price level as the preferred vehicle for excess cash. 
We have now reduced the diluted ending share count to 167 million, a 29% reduction from our share count and spend.  We currently have more than $1 billion available in our share repurchase program. 
Our company has significantly improved its operating and financial results since going public in 2012. We have a challenging first quarter 2014. We've improved our performance since then, meeting or exceeding our guidance again in 2015. 
On Slide 17, we highlight the quarterly trends for key financial and operational metrics for ADT. 
When analyzing in last 8 quarters, it's clear that our commitment to driving improvements in the 5 operating levers has been successful. Pre-SAC EBITDA and recurring revenue margins before special items has steadily improving throughout the year, ending their at their highest points since Q4. Steady-state free cash flow also had a new high this year, and we delivered 6% growth in gross adds for the year as we grew sequentially throughout 2015. Most important driver of our business is attrition, the improvements we have made over the last 6 quarters are significant as we improve attrition by 230 basis points. 
And last but not least, we've consistently lowered our direct SAC creation multiples throughout 2015 despite increases in automation take rates. 
We expect our focus on quality growth to continue to drive improvements to these metrics in 2016. 
So let's move to Slide 18 and address our 2016 guidance. We feel optimistic about the upcoming year due to the progress we've made in 2015 and initiatives we have underway and in the pipeline. 
We expect 2016 to be a year of improved operating metrics and financial growth, driven by an even greater focus on improving customer retention. This should drive better comp metrics, increased profitability and higher levels of free cash flow growth before special charges. 
The chart details our 5 primary financial and operating metric guidance for 2016. All growth levels are assumed to occur at constant exchange rates for prior year. 
Number one, we're calling for total revenue to grow between 3.5% and 4.5%. Most of this growth will come from increases in recurring revenue, although we also expect nonrecurring revenues to grow as we extend our commercial activities. 
We expect expansion activities in ADT Business and health to grow at accelerated rates. We also expect a modest level of recurring revenues in the launch of the LG all in one product. 
Two, we are targeting EBITDA before special items to grow in the range of $75 million to $90 million. Higher-quality sales by key leverage cost efficiencies, and synergies from the acquisition are expected to increase EBITDA margins for 2016. 
We'll also continue to invest in growth as we look to improve the customer experience, accelerate our expansion into the commercial market and launch our security offering targeted at the DIY marketplace. 
The EBITDA growth would have been higher if not for the estimated $12 million negative impact expected from the 53rd week we experienced in 2016. I will address this more in a moment. 
After finishing 2015 on a favorable note with $321 million of free cash flow before special items, we are guiding free cash flow to be higher for 2016. 
Better customer retention and more favorable mix of Pulse customers, higher ARPU and margins will drive at least 5% increase in free cash flow from operations. 
Somewhat mitigating this improvement is an expected increase in short-term interest rates. 
On the SAC side, we expect further improvements creation multiples resulting in capital spending increases, driven primarily by increasing gross adds and incremental Pulse upgrades. We do expect Pulse upgrades to temporarily increase in 2016 as we make a push to convert the remaining 2G customers to Pulse versus just replacing the radios. 
Four, improving the customer retention will continue to be our top priority in 2016. We are targeting net unit attrition to fall below 12% versus the Q4 rate of 12.2%. This will be driven by smarter customer acquisition, a retention program and higher account resales, particularly on relocation disconnects. 
And finally, we're targeting to increase our customer base in 2016 from our current position of 6.6 million costumers. 
In 2015, we lost about 70,000 customers, a 50% improvement over 2014. 
For 2016, we expect to grow gross adds, reduce customer disconnects and attract new customers via small opportunistic account acquisition at appropriate price levels. 
Two last points on guidance before I turn the call back to Naren for concluding comments. First, we're targeting the step up completion to 2G conversion program in the course of 2016. Technically, we have until calendar year end 2016 to complete this conversion. We'll be actively seeking to upgrade 2G customers to Pulse, but those who want, we'll just have to replace the radios. 
As is the case in 2015, we will report a special charge for the radio replacement cost. 
Lastly, I referred earlier to the 53rd week we report in 2016. Dating back to the Tyco period, ADT has utilized a 4 5 4 weekly calendar for reporting its quarterly earnings. 
This necessitates that once every 6 years or so, you have a 53rd week. 2016 is the year we have this extra week. 
As previously reported, our management and board have decided to use this timing to convert ADT to a traditional calendar month end period for reporting results beginning in 2016. 
Although this does not eliminate the 53rd week for 2016, it does ensure that this will not happen again and also aligns our reporting more appropriately with how we run the business. 
6 of this extra 7 days will occur in the first quarter as our reporting period begin on September 26 and ends December 31. 
Most of our revenues are monthly recurring revenues, so there is little impact to revenues as a result of the extra days. However, certain costs are negatively impacted such as hourly labor, desirable cost and marketing spend. 
For Q1, we expect the extra week to negatively impact EBITDA by $10 million EPS about $0.04. This impact this cash neutral and 1 time in nature. We expect Q1, 2017, to be incrementally favorable in 2016 by this onetime expense before factoring in any business improvement. 
Statistically, this will not affect our major operating metrics, only gross adds and gross disconnects will be affected by the extra days. 
Now I'd like to turn the call back over to Naren.

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. As I reflect on our first 3 years as a public company, I'm very proud of what our team has accomplished despite some bumps in the road. We completed a very complex separation from Tyco, which included over 100 shared IT systems, hundreds of
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. As I reflect on our first 3 years as a public company, I'm very proud of what our team has accomplished despite some bumps in the road. We completed a very complex separation from Tyco, which included over 100 shared IT systems, hundreds of co-located field offices and over 2 million customers monitoring lines, which needed to be moved between the 2 companies monitoring centers. During this time period, we also significantly strengthened our focus on enhancing the customer experience through adding more automation capabilities to our Pulse platform, improving customer service levels and screening out prospective customers who do not have the potential to become customers for life. 
These improvements resulted in 150 basis point improvement in customer retention. 
In addition, we continue to position ourselves for future profitable growth by investing in Pulse, expanding our business activities into the mid-sized commercial market, completing 2 acquisitions to bring new capabilities and increase our scale and coverage in the Canadian market and establishing new partnerships and solutions that will allow us to enter previously unpenetrated segments of the residential market. 
As a result of these investments, we've been able to grow Pulse customer base to over 1.5 billion customers, increase recurring revenue by nearly 15% and expand our customer base by 279,000 subscribers during our first 3 years as a standalone company. 
As I look forward over the next few years, I'm even more excited about the potential to further improve business performance and deliver profitable growth. 
Our focus on quality growth and enhancing the customer experience should allow us to bring customer attrition down to historic low levels for ADT, below 11%. This will put us on a path for consistent annual net ad growth organically. 
Our continued investment in and customer preference towards Pulse should result in Pulse growing to at least half of our customer base over the next few years. And I expect our new business platforms to continue to grow with our business and health channels growing double digits annually for the foreseeable future as a result of organic initiatives and some small acquisitions while our efforts in the previously unpenetrated residential market could attract up to 1 million new customers over the next several years. 
This growth should allow us to continue to improve our profitability and position us to deliver over $500 million worth of free cash flow annually, which will be used to further invest in the business or reward our shareholders with higher dividends and/or share repurchases. Needless to say, this is a very exciting path for ADT as we work hard to build on our market-leading position in the security and automation market. 
With that, we can open up the call for questions. Stephanie, can you provide the instructions for dialers to ask a question?

componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie, and good morning, and thank you for joining us for our call to discuss ADT's fourth quarter and full year results for fiscal 2015.With me on the call today are Naren Gursahaney, ADT's CEO; and Mike Geltzeiler, ADT's CFO.Let me be
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie, and good morning, and thank you for joining us for our call to discuss ADT's fourth quarter and full year results for fiscal 2015.
With me on the call today are Naren Gursahaney, ADT's CEO; and Mike Geltzeiler, ADT's CFO.
Let me begin by reminding everyone that the discussion today contain certain forward-looking statements about the company's future performance, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties and speak only as of today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ from these forward-looking statements are set forth within today's earnings release, which is furnished to the SEC in an 8-K report and in our Form 10-K for the year ended September 25, 2015, which we expect to file with the SEC later this week. 
In our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings release and slides, which are now posted on our website at adt.com and on our Investor Relations app, we have provided a reconciliation of the company's non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP. We urge you to review that information in conjunction with today's call.
For those of you following us on the webcast, we will be using the slide deck to supplement our commentary this morning. Please note that unless otherwise mentioned, references to our operating results exclude special items, and these metrics are non-GAAP financial metrics.
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Naren. Naren?

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. We hope you had a chance to review our previously issued earnings press release that highlights our results for the fourth quarter and our full fiscal year 2015.This morning,
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. We hope you had a chance to review our previously issued earnings press release that highlights our results for the fourth quarter and our full fiscal year 2015.
This morning, I will discuss our key performance highlights and accomplishments for the quarter and year. Then our CFO, Mike Geltzeiler, will provide additional details on our financial and operational performance as well as our outlook for 2016.
2015 was a pivotal year for ADT. We met or exceeded all of our major financial and operational goals and made further progress towards building a foundation for future profitable growth.
Our continued focus on customer retention and quality growth resulted in our key metric moving in the right direction again in the fourth quarter, reinforcing that we're pursuing the right strategies and priorities.
We continue to make smart investments in our business and establish new partnerships, positioning us well to execute upon our growth strategy. Many of the initiatives that fueled our performance in 2015 were launched in 2014 when we refocused our organization on improving customer retention by enhancing all aspects of the customer experience, attracting high-quality new customers in both our direct and dealer channels, selectively expanding into adjacent markets and exploring opportunities in previously unpenetrated markets.
As a result of our team's improved execution, the impact of these efforts first began to show through in our improved performance in the second half of 2014 and have continued to carry through in our results this past year. We're proud of what we've accomplished and remain confident that our best years are still in front of us.
The next 3 slides in the presentation deck reflect our report card for 2015.
I'll begin with the key operating levers that drive our results. Slide 3 shows our performance over the past year on the 4 operating levers that are affected by the competitive environment.
As you can see, we've delivered strong improvements in all 4 of these important levers. We increased gross adds across all lines of business and channels, improved customer retention by 130 basis points, increased new and resale ARPU by nearly 4% and reduced our direct channel creation multiple, which reflects the cash payback period for newly generated accounts.
This chart is evidence that we remain competitively strong and are extending our market leadership position, while improving overall business performance.
These operating levers fueled our improved performance in 2015. As shown on Slide 4, which highlight some of our key accomplishments, we delivered solid recurring revenue growth and improved financial results throughout the year. Customer adds increased by more than 6% over last year despite enhanced customer screening and other new customer onboarding requirements. We also focused a portion of our sales and marketing activities on Pulse upgrades, which rose 63% for the year.
Operationally, our primary focus continues to be on improved customer retention. For the year, we reduced attrition significantly, closing the year at 12.2% unit and revenue attrition, which is the lowest we have seen since the spin. This helped us reduce customer losses in 2015 and positions us well for net add growth in the future.
We also further reduced the cost of adding new customers to the ADT family, resulting in our lowest creation multiples since we became a public company despite a steady increase in Pulse take rates. And speaking of Pulse, we increased total Pulse customers by 50% during the year, reaching 1.5 million customers.
As I stated previously, Pulse was a standalone company, it would be the second largest residential security company in North America, only behind ADT. On the strategic front, we further strengthened our competitive position and paved the way for future profitable growth by expanding into new market segments and entering into key partnerships to improve our product portfolio.
This year, we launched ADT Business, supporting our expansion in the small business channel and entry into the mid-size commercial market. Our business channel delivered double-digit year-over-year new customer growth this year, and we're still in the early stages of our commercial expansion.
We also enhanced our health business with a launch of our Mobile PERS solution with fall detection and added new distribution channels. We've opened up our Pulse ecosystem and partnered with innovative companies like Nest Labs to allow ADT customers to integrate with best-of-breed products, like the Nest Learning Thermostat. After a successful launch in 4 pilot markets, we're now making this integration available for our Pulse automation customers nationwide.
We also launched the new ADT owned Pulse mobile app with more intuitive and easier navigation for our Pulse customers.
And lastly, in collaboration with LG, we announced a new all-in-one security device with ADT monitoring services to target the unpenetrated North America residential market, including renters and frequent movers.
We've made significant progress on the product, associated services and retail distribution strategy, and we are now targeting the first calendar quarter of 2016 for our launch. We're very excited about what this means for our business in the future.
On Slide #5, you can see our overall performance was strong, as we met or exceeded our guidance for 2015 on a constant-currency basis. And on Slide #6, you can see some of our achievements for the fourth quarter. Mike will cover the quarter in greater detail, but I wanted to mention a couple items. 
Overall, our operating metrics continued to move in the right direction, highlighted by another drop in net unit attrition, which improved 100 basis points year-over-year and net revenue attrition, which improved 130 basis points from last year. Both ended the year at 12.2%.
We generated 278,000 gross adds, about flat with prior year excluding bulk account purchases, as we continue to focus on quality customer additions that will provide longer tenure and higher financial returns.
These strong operating metrics fueled growth in revenues, EBITDA and free cash flow on a year-over-year basis.
Although we've shared Slide #7 before, I want to spend a minute on our strategy to create shareholder value as I think this reflects our strategic priorities very well. Our strategy is focused on 3 areas: growing our traditional business, selectively expanding it to near adjacencies and partnering to target the nontraditional residential market.
The dynamics of our industry continue to be positive creating a tremendous opportunity for ADT. A key driver of our opportunity continues to be growing consumer interest in smart home and Internet of Things devices, along with their desire to be in control and safe. And security remains at the top of the list of reasons for this consumer interest, which is great news for ADT. These changing market dynamics in the residential market, combined with the investments we're making in commercial and health, result in a very large market opportunity for ADT.
In total, we expect our addressable market to nearly triple over the next 5 years to over 70 million potential customers. We're coupling these growth activities with our strong balance sheet and are focused on optimizing our capital structure and capital allocation. We continue to reinvest cash to support this organic growth, remain disciplined in our strategic M&A activities and are returning excess capital to our shareholders via dividends and opportunistic share buybacks.
At the heart of our strategy is our focus on customer retention. As shown on Slide 8, we are continuing to strengthen and refine our focus on improving customer retention by doing 3 basic things: one, bringing on the right customer; two, onboarding them in the right way; and three, providing them a great customer experience. Doing these 3 things right is the key to further reductions in attrition and the right formula for improving customer economics and generating higher free cash flow.
We've made much progress over the past 2 years in improving in these areas, which is why we've seen a significant improvements in retention and net add performance. However, with new tools and analytics now at our disposal, giving us better insights into customer behavior and tendencies, we will make further improvements in the future.
We started last year with enhanced tenure screening to target higher quality customers upfront before we spend money to add them into our network. This effort alone has filtered out nearly 16,000 potential customer adds in the year and has contributed to a significant drop in attrition in the nonpay category.
With the additional insights into customer behavior and the new tools, such as our electronic order management platform, we are continuing to refine our approach and putting in place new customer requirements that will result in more engaged and longer tenure customers.
Improving the customer experience is at the core of our strategy and Pulse customers continue to exhibit better economics and retention.
On Slide #9, you can see that over 59% of our total gross adds during the quarter were Pulse units, up from 51% a year ago. In our residential direct channel, the Pulse take rate for new and resale units was 65%. While more than 75% of our new residential customers added via this channel were Pulse customers.
In our dealer channel, the Pulse take rate ramped up to 57% from about 47% last year. And in our small business channel, the Pulse take rate was 41%.
In addition to new Pulse sales, we also upgraded about 39,000 existing customers this quarter. Pulse upgrades allow us to provide additional service to our existing customers and yield higher ARPU.
In addition, these upgrades allow us to enhance the customer experience and enter into new contracts. We now have approximately 1.5 million Pulse customers with total interactive customers now comprising about 23% of our customer base.
As we discussed during our Investor Day, Pulse customers continue to demonstrate better retention characteristics than traditional security customers.
Our analysis also shows that retention further improves when customers choose automation features such as thermostats, light switches, door locks and cameras. Equally is important, our initial data also shows that the resale rate, the rate at which we sign up a new customer who moves into a home where Pulse automation is already installed, is higher as compared to non-Pulse customers.
Now let me turn things over to Mike to provide some additional details on our financial and operational performance for the quarter and year.

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Naren. 2015 was a transitional year for ADT, in which we improved both our operational and financial performance, positioning the company for future growth and increased profitability.In our core operations, this means a disciplined, more acute
componenttext:
Thanks, Naren. 2015 was a transitional year for ADT, in which we improved both our operational and financial performance, positioning the company for future growth and increased profitability.
In our core operations, this means a disciplined, more acute focus on customer economics and return on invested capital. Hence, the term smart growth, quality growth and profitable growth is describing our business objectives.
As Naren said, by enhancing the customer experience and using data analytics to drive our customer acquisition practices, we believe we can attract the right customers with the right offerings, at the appropriate SAC and ensure that these customers remain with us longer. This approach does put some top line pressure on gross add growth with dividends and customer retention, lower SAC, higher margins and increased free cash flow. As we look ahead to 2016, we expect more or the same. I will discuss 2016 guidance later in my remarks.
First, I'll review our Q4 and full year performance. Slide 10 summarizes our GAAP and non-GAAP financial results for the quarter. In Q4, recurring revenue, which accounts for approximately 93% of our total revenue, grew 2% to $835 million and total revenue increased by 1.8% to $899 million.
Recurring revenue growth outpaced total revenue growth as we continue to add different products and services to our portfolio, that generate recurring revenue in place of lower-margin onetime sales.
For example, late in 2014, our business channel began to offer hosted video services, that generate recurring revenue in place of onetime DVR sales.
All this being said, in 2016, we will have the opportunity to grow nonrecurring revenue as our commercial channel continues to gain traction, and we broadened our service capabilities and product offerings.
When adjusting for the Canadian dollar, which impacts approximately 10% of our total revenues and has declined significantly versus prior year, recurring revenue was up 3.4% and total revenue increased by 3.3%.
In Q4, reported operating expenses before special items were up 3.9% over the last year, including a 5% increase in depreciation and amortization.
Excluding the $8 million impact of the marketing efficiency program, total operating expenses before special items were up just 2.7% in the quarter.
Besides depreciation, the increase in total expenses was driven by the growth of Pulse, investments in our commercial expansion and development of our new Pulse app and all-in-one DIY product as well as investments we have made to improve our service levels.
EBITDA before special items was $460 million, which includes a negative impact of approximately $8 million related to the previously disclosed change in the way we account for our marketing efficiency program as well as a negative impact of approximately $5 million due to the decline of the Canadian dollar.
Adjusting for these 2 items, EBITDA was $15 million favorable at a prior year. EBITDA margin for the quarter was 51.2%, 100 basis point improvement from Q3. Improvement reflects continued execution of our cost efficiency program. Excluding special items, non-GAAP diluted EPS was $0.51, which includes the impact of $0.03 per share related to the prior mentioned marketing efficiency program. This compares to non-GAAP diluted EPS of $0.55 per share last year. Using our Q4 cash tax rate, diluted earnings per share before special items was $0.73 for the quarter. Our effective tax rate was 30.8% compared with 24.8% last year.
Slide 10 also details our special items for the quarter. In Q4, we continue to make progress on our 2G radio conversion program, upgrading or converting nearly 40,000 customers in the quarter for a total of approximately 276,000 for the year.
We have made significant progress since the start of this project and have about 500,000 customers left who either need to upgrade or convert to a new radio. We plan to complete most of these conversions in fiscal 2016 and finalize the program in our first quarter of fiscal 2017.
Turning to the operating levers. Slide 11 shows gross adds and average revenue per unit for Q4. Overall, total company gross adds, excluding bulk acquisitions were 278,000, the highest level of 2015 of flat versus last year.
Our company's focus on quality growth combined with enhanced tenure screening created some slight headwinds to overall year-over-year growth, but resulted in better financial results. Gross adds in our direct channel were up slightly, offset by dealer gross additions, which were nearly flat to last year. Gross adds for ADT Business were up 17% and health adds were higher by 27%. Pricing continues to be an area of strength, as both average and new and resale ARPU continue to grow in the fourth quarter.
Overall, pricing remains healthy in our business as we continue to drive higher Pulse take rates with greater automation and grow our business channel, which has a higher ARPU.
For the quarter, new and resale ARPU was $48.40, an increase of 3.4% over the prior year. Our ARPU for the overall customer base was $42.65, an increase of nearly 3% year-over-year. When adjusting for the Canadian FX, ARPU was up by 4% over last year. As I indicated earlier, the company is committed to pursuing profitable growth and enhancing customer experience, which leads to greater customer retention and loyalty.
Slide 12 shows the progress we've made on customer retention. Attrition has improved for 6 consecutive quarters, reaching a new low in Q4. Net revenue attrition was 12.2%, sequential improvement of 20 basis points and a significant reduction of 130 basis points versus last year. Unit attrition, which measures customer attrition for just our residential and business customers, was also 12.2% for the quarter, a 10 basis point improvement versus Q3 and 100 basis points lower than last year.
Improvements are led by the progress we've made in gross attrition throughout 2015, as we reduced nonpay, voluntary and lost the competition disconnections, combined with a 21% year-over-year increase in resales.
Relocations skewed higher this quarter as the housing market improved, but this is more than offset by attrition improvement elsewhere and by the higher resales.
We are pleased with the progress we've made this year as our attrition results are materially favorable to both our guidance and prior year results. However, we see ample opportunity to perform better and are targeting further improvement in 2016.
Slide 13 shows our quarterly results for recurring revenue margin and SAC creation multiples. For the quarter, recurring revenue margin in our existing customer base was about 66.6% compared to 67.5% in last year. While the recurring revenue margin is down versus last year, it increased sequentially by 70 basis points in Q4.
Margins throughout the year have been pressured by our investments to expand into commercial, development of our new Pulse app and costs associated with the launch of our all-in-one DIY product.
Additionally, increased spending to improve customer service levels and response times have negatively impacted margins, but contributed to improvements in customer experience and attrition.
SAC is another favorable story for 2015. We've consistently lowered SAC in 2015 through marketing efficiencies, sales effectiveness and the installation processes by implementing electronic contracts, Total Security panel and lower cost equipment.
Our combined net creation multiple improved by 0.8x to 29.8x in Q4, while the net creation multiple in our direct channel fell to 29.1x, a onetime improvement versus last year. 
Net SAC in our direct channel fell to nearly $1,400, below the average SAC levels in Q4 2014. We have lowered both total and direct channel creation multiples, excluding upgrades in every quarter this year, while also increasing Pulse take rates.
Slide 14 details the components of our fourth quarter free cash flow results. The charts aggregate cash flow into cash generated from existing customers and cash invested to secure a new or upgrade existing customers.
Free cash flow before special items was $77 million in Q4, up $23 million or 43% versus last year. It's the second consecutive quarter of free cash flow growth, enabling us to finish 2015 with free cash flow before special items of $321 million, which is about 30% higher than the 2015 figure we baselined at our Investor Day in May.
Pre-SAC, free cash flow before special items was driven by lower attrition, operational improvements and growth in Pulse customers.
For the quarter, pre-SAC free cash flow before special items increased by 5.6% to $510 million, up $27 million from last year.
Investing in new customer growth is the main driver behind our ability to generate future free cash flow and our quality growth initiatives enable us to focus on the customers, which we feel are most likely to meet our return criteria.
Total SAC before special items for the quarter was $433 million, marginally above the $429 million in Q4 last year. For the year, free cash flow from our existing customers increased $116 million to almost $2 billion. This was partially offset by a $1.7 billion investment in new customers. 
This investment represents an increase of about 8%, driven by a 6% growth in gross adds and about 50,000 more Pulse upgrades.
Slide 15 highlights the improvements we've made in our steady-state free cash flow results over last year. Steady-state free cash flow is a long-term valuation metric, which allows us to measure the free cash flow generated by maintaining the recurring revenue from our existing customer base before investing in new subscriber growth.
The key drivers to this symmetric, pre-SAC EBITDA, SAC creation multiples and attrition are all continuing to move in the right direction, which allowed us to improve our results over last year.
Steady-state free cash flow before special items was $996 million, up $30 million versus prior year. When analyzing results in constant currency, steady-state free cash flow exceeded our guidance of $1 billion. 
Slide 16 highlights our capital allocation and debt levels for the quarter. Trailing 12-month leverage reached 3x EBITDA and trailing 12-month debt-to-pre-SAC EBITDA was 2.4x.
As a reminder, we began reporting pre-SAC leverage ratio to provide a harmonized view similar to how most, if not all, our security competitors report leverage by removing the expense investment in new subscribers.
In addition, our EBITDA results were negatively impacted by about $25 million in 2015 as a result of the noncash change in how we report the marketing efficiency program. Our long-term leverage target remains 3x EBITDA.
Our total cost of borrowing was below 4% in Q4 and our debt continues to trade at favorable levels. Having a low cost of borrowing provides us the flexibility to invest in growth and return capital to our shareholders.
In the fourth quarter, we paid a quarterly dividend of $0.21 per share or 5% increase over last year.
In Q4, we also repurchased 4.3 million shares at an average price of $32.70 per share, contributing to the total of 9.8 million shares for $324 million of repurchases for fiscal 2015.
With our cash flow increasing, our business stable and our growth initiatives adequately funded, we continue to view share repurchases at current price level as the preferred vehicle for excess cash.
We have now reduced the diluted ending share count to 167 million, a 29% reduction from our share count and spend. We currently have more than $1 billion available in our share repurchase program.
Our company has significantly improved its operating and financial results since going public in 2012. We've had a challenging first quarter 2014. We've improved our performance since then, meeting or exceeding our guidance again in 2015.
On Slide 17, we highlight the quarterly trends for key financial and operational metrics for ADT.
When analyzing last 8 quarters, it's clear that our commitment to driving improvements in the 5 operating levers has been successful. Pre-SAC EBITDA and recurring revenue margins before special items has been steadily improving throughout the year, ending at their highest points since Q4. Steady-state free cash flow also had a new high this year, and we delivered 6% growth in gross adds for the year, as we grew sequentially throughout 2015. The most important driver of our business is attrition. The improvements we've made in the last 6 quarters are significant, as we improved attrition by 230 basis points.
And last but not least, we've consistently lowered our direct SAC creation multiples throughout 2015, despite increases in automation take rates.
We expect our focus on quality growth to continue to drive improvements to these metrics in 2016.
So let's move to Slide 18 and address our 2016 guidance. We feel optimistic about the upcoming year due to the progress we've made in 2015 and the initiatives we have underway and in the pipeline.
We expect 2016 to be a year of improved operating metrics and financial growth, driven by an even greater focus on improving customer retention. This should drive better customer metrics, increased profitability and higher levels of free cash flow growth before special charges.
The chart details our 5 primary financial and operating metric guidance for 2016. All growth levels are assumed to occur at constant exchange rates with prior year. 
Number one, we're calling for total revenue to grow between 3.5% and 4.5%. Most of this growth will come from increases in recurring revenue, although we also expect nonrecurring revenues to grow as we extend our commercial activities. We expect expansion activities in ADT Business and health to grow at accelerated rates. We also expect a modest level of recurring revenues from the launch of the LG all-in-one product.
Two, we are targeting EBITDA before special items to grow in the range of $75 million to $90 million. Higher-quality sales by key leverage cost efficiencies and synergies from the Protectron integration are expected to increase EBITDA margins for 2016.
We'll also continue to invest in growth as we look to improve the customer experience, accelerate our expansion into the commercial market and launch our security offering targeted at the DIY marketplace.
The EBITDA growth would have been higher, if not for the estimated $12 million negative impact, expected from the 53rd week we'll experienced in 2016. I will address this more in a moment. After finishing 2015 on a favorable note with $321 million of free cash flow before special items, we are guiding free cash flow to be higher for 2016.
Better customer retention and more favorable mix of Pulse customers, higher ARPU and margins will drive at least 5% increase in free cash flow from operations.
Somewhat mitigating this improvement is an expected increase in short-term interest rates.
On the SAC side, we expect further improvements in subscriber creation multiples resulting in capital spending increases, driven primarily by increasing gross adds and incremental Pulse upgrades. We do expect Pulse upgrades to temporarily increase in 2016 as we make a push to convert the remaining 2G customers to Pulse versus just replacing the radios.
Four, improving the customer retention will continue to be our top priority in 2016. We are targeting net unit attrition to fall below 12% versus the Q4 rate of 12.2%. This will be driven by smarter customer acquisition, a retention program and higher account resales, particularly on relocation disconnects. 
And finally, we're targeting to increase our customer base in 2016 from our current position of 6.6 million costumers.
In 2015, we lost about 70,000 customers, a 50% improvement over 2014.
For 2016, we expect to grow gross adds, reduce customer disconnects and attract new customers via small opportunistic account acquisitions at appropriate price levels.
Two last points on guidance before I turn the call back to Naren for concluding comments. First, we're targeting to step-up completion to the 2G conversion program in the course of 2016. Technically, we have until calendar year-end 2016 to complete this conversion. We'll be actively seeking to upgrade 2G customers to Pulse, but those that won't will just have to replace their radios.
As was the case in 2015, we will report a special charge for the radio replacement cost.
Lastly, I referred earlier to the 53rd week we report in 2016. Dating back to the Tyco period, ADT has utilized a 4-5-4 weekly calendar for reporting its quarterly earnings. This necessitates that once every 6 years or so, you have a 53rd week. 2016 is the year we have this extra week.
As previously reported, our management and Board have decided to use this timing to convert ADT to a traditional calendar month-end period for reporting results beginning in 2016.
Although this does not eliminate the 53rd week for 2016, it does ensure that this will not happen again and also aligns our reporting more appropriately with how we run the business.
Six of the extra 7 days will occur in the first quarter as our reporting period began on September 26 and ends December 31.
Most of our revenues are monthly recurring revenues, so there is little impact to revenues as a result of the extra days. However, certain costs are negatively impacted such as hourly labor, [indiscernible] cost and marketing spend.
For Q1, we expect the extra week to negatively impact EBITDA by $10 million and EPS about $0.04. This impact is cash neutral and one-time in nature. We expect Q1 2017 to be incrementally favorable than 2016 by this one-time expense before factoring in any business improvement.
Statistically, this will not affect our major operating metrics. Only gross adds and gross disconnects will be affected by the extra days.
Now I'd like to turn the call back over to Naren.

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. As a reflect on our first 3 years as a public company, I'm very proud of what our team has accomplished despite some bumps in the road. We completed a very complex separation from Tyco, which included over 100 shared IT systems, hundreds of
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. As a reflect on our first 3 years as a public company, I'm very proud of what our team has accomplished despite some bumps in the road. We completed a very complex separation from Tyco, which included over 100 shared IT systems, hundreds of co-located field offices and over 2 million customer monitoring lines, which needed to be moved between the 2 companies monitoring centers. During this time period, we also significantly strengthened our focus on enhancing the customer experience through adding more automation capabilities to our Pulse platform, improving customer service levels and screening out prospective customers who do not have the potential to become customers for life. These improvements resulted in 150 basis point improvement in customer retention.
In addition, we continue to position ourselves for future profitable growth by investing in Pulse, expanding our business activities into the mid-size commercial market, completing 2 acquisitions to bring new capabilities and increase our scale and coverage in the Canadian market, and establishing new partnerships and solutions that will allow us to enter previously unpenetrated segments of the residential market.
As a result of these investments, we've been able to grow Pulse customer base to over 1.5 million customers, increased recurring revenue by nearly 15% and expand our customer base by 279,000 subscribers during our first 3 years as a standalone company.
As I look forward over the next few years, I'm even more excited about the potential to further improve business performance and deliver profitable growth.
Our focus on quality growth and enhancing the customer experience should allow us to bring customer attrition down to historic low levels for ADT, below 11%. This will put us on a path for consistent annual net add growth organically.
Our continued investment in customer preference towards Pulse should result in Pulse growing to at least half of our customer base over the next few years. And I expect our new business platforms to continue to grow with our business and health channels growing double digits annually for the foreseeable future as a result of organic initiatives and some small acquisitions while our efforts in the previously unpenetrated residential market could attract up to 1 million new customers over the next several years. 
This growth should allow us to continue to improve our profitability and position us to deliver over $500 million worth of free cash flow annually, which will be used to further invest in the business or reward our shareholders with higher dividends and/or share repurchases. Needless to say, this is a very exciting path for ADT as we work hard to build on our market-leading position in the security and automation market.
With that, we can open up the call for questions. Stephanie, can you provide the instructions for dialers to ask a question?

componenttext: Yes, really, the only effect that this extra week will have on our revenues is a for nonrecurring revenue, which as you know is miniscule. We're $64 million for the quarter. So nonrecurring revenue is revenue we record everyday. We have 7 more days to realize nonrecurring revenue. So that is the only impact. The reason it will not affect regular revenue is -- the best way to kind of describe that is describe it on a monthly basis. In the month of February, a customer pays $45 for the services, whether it's 8 days in that month or 30 days or 31, we charged a monthly fee, we don't charge a per day fee. So we are booking -- we're charging customers who are going to pay 1/12 of -- or they're going to pay their annual amount divided by 12. So recurring revenues has been -- is not affected by this extra week. We still will have the same amount of months as we had last year. So it really only affects -- and as true, a lot of our fixed cost and our salaries aren't affected either. It's really the hourly cost and the strict variable cost like marketing as well as nonrecurring revenue. So revenues are not affected by this. The customer will still pay 12x their monthly amount. It will be [indiscernible] years worth regardless of how many days are in a month.

And some of the things we've talked about in the past are the products they buy. We've talked about the fact that ADT Pulse automation, our customers have higher retention. So clearly, we want to be pursuing more customers who are implying to buy Pulse and Pulse Automation specifically. We've indicated that those who buy life safety solutions versus just intrusion solutions tend to be stickier. How they pay, again, and I think we've been very good at this by making sure that we get credit card or ACH payment. And then, I'd say the final thing that we continue to look at is how much the customer invests upfront. It's their level of engagement is driven by the investment that they make upfront. So it's a variety of parameters. I think our analytics are much better than they were 2 years ago, 3 years ago. We have a much better understanding of what are the ideal and optimal characteristics and we're gearing our sales force into pursuing those kinds, not just those kinds of customers, but those kinds of sale characteristics.

componenttext: So on the health side, I'd say, yes, it changed both in the product over the past 2 years but then also the distribution channels for the product. As you're probably aware, if you go back 2 years ago, we simply had a landline base in-home solution. We supplemented that with a cellular product that allowed us to at least serve customers who didn't have a landline. And then, in February of this year, we introduced the Mobile PERS solutions that isn't even necessarily tied to a home, it got GPS in it. So you can use it on-the-go. Similarly, both for our wireless product and our mobile product, we added fall detection. So that gives you fall, you don't have to reach out and hit the button to call our monitoring center, the product detects that. And our monitoring center will call the individual to reach out through via that pendant or that bracelet. So we have changed and added the products, and those makeup more than 50% of our sales these days. And we are seeing good take rates on the fall detection as well. From a channel perspective, it is more looking at bulk sales. Looking at nursing homes or other organizations that may have large versus a traditional residential model, where you're looking at individual consumers. We're continuing to sell through individual consumers, but we're also looking at more of those bigger account opportunities, and we've retooled the sales force, brought in a new sales leader to pursue those kinds of opportunities. So we expect to see continued acceleration there. And we're also working with retailers to see if there's an opportunity to sell either in the store or more likely via their websites. We've used e-commerce sales on our own platform.
