headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've been indicating, it's about $200, may be a little bit less, depending on whether we -- some of those will be upgraded, so we wouldn't put that as a cost if it's upgraded because that would be a -- they sign a new contract for 3 years. So we indicate
componenttext: We've been indicating, it's about $200, may be a little bit less, depending on whether we -- some of those will be upgraded, so we wouldn't put that as a cost if it's upgraded because that would be a -- they sign a new contract for 3 years. So we indicated somewhere in the $85 million to $100 million range to complete the program. And I'm not saying that is all next year, we have 5 quarters to do that. But again, the more we upgrade, the less that charge would be. We'll upgrade them to Pulse, and they'll sign another 3-year contract, et cetera. So I think the mix has something to do with the ultimate cost. But it's been running. If you look at the math and the numbers I gave you, we spent $55 million this year for 270 million -- 270,000 customers of which some were upgraded. So it's about $200 a house.

componenttext: Just want to touch on the kind of M&A pipeline just what you're seeing out there and if it's not as robust as it kind of has been in the past, should we expect more share repurchases going into 2016 or 2015?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll talk about that. The pipeline is interesting. We're seeing -- there is a decent amount of consolidation interest, people who are in the market, I think there's still pretty high expectation for, one of the reasons we have -- again, everything wi
componenttext: Yes, I'll talk about that. The pipeline is interesting. We're seeing -- there is a decent amount of consolidation interest, people who are in the market, I think there's still pretty high expectation for, one of the reasons we have -- again, everything with us is remaining disciplined, so we look at a lot of things and as you can see this year we have not done much in the way of consolidation and tuck-unders. I think, the price needs to be right. There's been a couple of transaction in the space. But a lot of businesses are -- people that say, "If I can get this price, I will sell. If I can't, I won't." And so I think we have a pretty good pipeline of business that we're interested in. And we think it is an opportunity for us for sure. But again, as we said, it needs to be at the right price. To us, some of these things we're looking at, particularly, the smaller to medium-size opportunities. This is really a third way to acquire our customers. Some are even asset deals, they are not even business acquisitions. So you're mostly buying accounts with a couple of salespeople. So I got to look at it relative to what my dealers and/or my direct team can deliver and make sure those return metrics are there. So we remain optimistic with that channel. I think it's not -- I think we remain one of the larger buyers out there, so if someone wants to sell, we'll be the ones who could make that. But I think at this stage, when I compare that to where my stock trades at, sub-40, RMR, it's why we believe that the best buy in security is our own stock.

componenttext: I mean, when we originally did the deal, we indicated $10 million to $15 million range and I think we're very confident with that number. As Naren mentioned the management team is in place. Some of the -- we've gotten some of that clearly, by '16 will be an acceleration of that. And some of the larger opportunities do require some integration of systems and things; a lot of that work is underway as we speak. So I think by the end of '16, we'll be at the run rate of what we're looking for. It doesn't mean we're going to be realizing it all in '16, but to sort of integrate the 2 billing systems and some of the customer systems is going to require certainly some -- a significant amount of work up in Canada. I think they have a great plan to do that. So I think you're going to look in the -- possibly, in the higher range of that range of $10 million to $15 million.

componenttext: Yes, I think we got to keep in mind when we do a deal like that we look at everything on cash basis. Some of it will show up in SAC and free cash improvements.

And also just kind of part of that, I was wondering, it obviously makes sense to kind of try to attract higher-quality customers on any day in any business, but does that focus in any way indicate that some of the experience on the early Pulse customers hasn't been quite as good as you thought, and so there's a further kind of level of scrutiny and screening around Pulse, specifically, sorry for the multipart?

headline: The ADT Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, starting on the Pulse -- on the automation side, I think it's north of 40% of our new Pulse customer that are coming with automation, so that's on the new side. When you look at it from a base perspective, I expected it's higher than that from a ba
componenttext: First, starting on the Pulse -- on the automation side, I think it's north of 40% of our new Pulse customer that are coming with automation, so that's on the new side. When you look at it from a base perspective, I expected it's higher than that from a base perspective, again, because it's got better retention. And over time, if we are losing Pulse customers, we would be losing more non-automation customers. The attrition rate, again, continues to be very good. I would refer back to some of the data we shared in our Investor Day and things are continuing to hold there. As far as the quality growth piece, Jeff, again, I think what's happening is our ability to segment the data and segment customers better through our analytics is what's helping us just be a little bit more surgical in our approach. I think when you look at the economics on our portfolio basis, they've always been very good. We've talked about what the IRRs are. Now what we can do is we can surgically "remove" some of those less attractive customers within a tranche and focus on the more attractive customers. So again, while we are walking away from some of business, it will help not just our operating metrics, but it will help the overall profitability and free cash flow for the company. And we know how important that this to our shareholders, and we want to make sure that we're using every penny wisely for them.
